Mika was not seen in the saltlick, maybe she fissioned before. They did not go down to the ground (no pictures in the camera) and Peccaries, antbirds, capuchins and tamarins went through. They ate some Virola and then started moving towards the Puma Plot. At 11.00 Sammy, Andreo, Kauo, Sofia and Mono (?) joined them. The group emitted a lot of long calls and kept on moving north. At 11:54 we hit Maquisapa 2150. They moved further north. Monica and I had the impression they were looking for MQ-3. But at 12:30 it started raining and they seemed to change their mind and went back south. We crossed Maquisapa 2150 at 12:17 again. Then they stayed in the same area for about 3 hours. They fed on a couple of trees and rested (it was still raining). At 15:45 they started heading north again and we lost them."OS07317		Rebecca Rimbach	3/5/08	1/0/00									FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"We found Andreo and Lucas at AB-08-187 where they were calling in the early morning probably; looking for other individuals. They started moving fast towards Guacamayo and kept on moving into the flooded area. We lost them for 20 minutes and found them again in Guacamayo 2500 where they were coming north from the flood. During this time they fusioned with 2 other males; Poto and Nenki. The 4 males went into the flooded area next to the lagoon just next to the tower, and began to emit longcalls. Nenki was ranging with the males and started emitting squeaks when other individuals (probably Nipa) started vocalizing several 100 meters east. Nenki fissioned and started moving fast towards where the females were calling. Lucas separated from the other males and started moving towards the north bordering the lagoon area and went into the flooded area where other individuals were far west. We lost everyone. 
We found Vita, Eva, Ana, Evita and Oikamo with kids just north of the saltlick. They headed into the saltlick area at midday and they waited for several hours in the upper part of the canopy (probably waiting for someone else to come). They did not try to go down. They went out to the puma ridge where they foraged. Nipa, Nenki and Luna fusioned and shortly after the fusion there was a large aggression from 3 females towards Vita. There were lots of growls and Vita squealed several times. Just after the aggression all the females headed towards the saltlick again. While they were there Andreo appeared and went into the saltlick too. We still do not know if they went down. At around 16:00 they went out of the saltlick area and headed very spread out towards the flooded area in Songo Songo. They fissioned into several smaller subgroups. Luna left by herself Eva, Ana, Nipa and Oikamo were together and we do not know where Vita, Evita and Andreo left. After that Oikamo and Nipa and Nenki separated from Ana and Eva and went north where they met with Luna and went to sleep."OS07318		Rebecca Rimbach	3/15/08	1/0/00									FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	OS07319		Rebecca Rimbach	3/16/08	1/0/00									FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	OS07320		Rebecca Rimbach	3/17/08	1/0/00									FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	OS07321		Rebecca Rimbach	3/18/08	1/0/00							Lagoon is flooded again. At 6:28 we crossed Guacamayo 725, then they fed in a Sapotaceae (AB-08-225) and we crossed Puma 175. Then the group went into the saltlick area. At 9:40 we checked if the group was still in the saltlick but we could not find the monkeys. So we started searching for them.
At 10:38 we found them resting close to Guacamayo 350. At 11:20 we crossed Danta 50 and they went to AB-08-224. Then we went back to Guacamayo 350 and back to the saltlick area. But they did not stay in the area but left it soon after going in. When they went out it started raining heavily and we lost the monkeys.
Note: After the first time in the saltlick we did not see Sammy and Mono again. Maybe they fissioned."OS07367		Rebecca Rimbach	5/9/08	1/0/00									FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	OS07368		Arden Rienas	6/8/08	1/0/00									FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	OS07369		Maryjka Today I went with Tony and Kelsey to dart one of the woolly monkeys. We were happy having coffee before leaving and we heard some monkeys near the Comedor, towards Numa. We saw spider monkeys moving on Numa 25 at 6:39am (AV10151). They were probably Cotinga, Ceiba and an adult male (I think it was Poto). We followed them by Numa and Matapalo until they arrived to the Brosimum LL-06-047 around 7:09am. They started eating from the feeding tree. Woolly monkeys were also there (AV10152), probably group Y. Some of them were resting, others were feeding at the same time with at least two spider monkeys (Cotinga and Ceiba). We saw 3 adult females with dependent infants, one adult female (buff female) with a juvenile female, two adult male (one big adult male, one smaller Ð Clash), one subadult male, and another juvenile (?). Spider monkeys left the Brosimum tree and we stayed with the woolly monkeys to try and dart one of them. Tony darted the big adult male at 11:07. He fell off at 11:13 but he got stuck in branches and didnÕt fall. He started moving again around 12:00 but moving only arms or legs, but remained in the same spot. He was vigilant looking around, while the rest of the group were moving around and vocalizing. He started moving between trees around 12:30. We kept following them and at 13:21 Tony darted a smaller male (CLASH). While he was still groggy, a subadult/juvenile (?) male was looking at him and was moving close to him ( ~ 3 meters below). Then the subadult/juvenile male kept moving and began foraging in the adjacent tree. Others were around. Clash fell down at 13:31 and we brought him back to the lab for processing. We put on a collar with frequency 151.600 and a green diamond ID tag. The VHF has red tape on it. While he was in the recovery bag, he pooped all overÉ it smelled awful! He also chewed a lot on the antenna. Around 4:20pm we took him back to the spot were he was darted and released him. He went up with no problem, but he was trying very hard to take of his collar. After a while he started foraging and then stayed up in the canopy. There were other woollies around, we were able to hear them replying after Clash vocalized, but we werenÕt able to see them. We stayed with him until 17:50, and he remained in the same spot."OS17018		Laura Abondano	6/5/13	1/0/00							5:53 we arrive to where Nelson left Mono and Julieta sleeping last night. Today I went with Tony, Nelson and Miguel to find the MQ-1 spider monkeys that Nelson and Miguel left sleeping yesterday near Puma Plot 3-700. We were trying to dart Mono or any other male. We waited until they (Mono and Julieta) started moving at 6:03am. They ate a while from a Guarea tree and afterwards they went into a very entangled tree where we were not able to see them. They rested from 6:30 to 7am. After that they started moving and Mono began to move west, leaving Julieta behind (fission at 7:15). He moved west in the Puma Plot where he fed a while from the Naucleopsis tree AB-13-108, and he rested again from 7:48 to 8:49am near the tree AB-13-108. At 10:06 there was a fusion with Sofia and Summer who arrived where Mono was. They moved a bit towards Maquisapa trail (~ MS3900) and there we saw Sofia presenting to Mono several times, where she would present her back to him, like trying to copulate. In one instance, Mono was behind her but we didnÕt see them copulating, but when they stopped being in contact (after one minute or so) we saw that Mono was having an erection. We also saw that every time Sofia approached Mono he showed teeth to her and sometimes he was ÒshooingÓ her by lunging his arm towards her trying to get her away from him. He also chased her once down a tree until she left (after we saw him with an erection). After resting for about an hour Sofia began heading back towards the moretal and Mono stayed in the same spot (fission at 12:10). At 14:00 we saw Sammy (fusion) and they stayed in the same spot for a while, and then Sofia and Summer also joined at 14:14. They were all moving around the area, but not really moving in a specific direction. At 14:59 we saw Sofia feeding from an Iriartea tree, and as soon as Summer went inside the tree, Sofia chased him down until she kicked him out of the tree. At 15:20 we saw Sofia moving again towards the moretal (?) and we think we stayed with the males but we are not sure since we were not able to see them again."OS17019		Laura Abondano	6/6/13	1/0/00							We arrive to Numa at 6:05 and wait to hear the spider monkeys with Miguel. Today I went with all the primate crew (Tony, Nelson, Kelsey and Miguel) to look for RodmanÕs group in the Harpia Plot. We first found them at 7:50 near HP line 3-900 where we left them yesterday. Tony darted a male but he didnÕt fall. We waited for an hour and a half to see if he moved but no monkey jumped out of the tree so we left, but we were able to hear woolly monkeys towards northwest and south of where the monkey was darted. We left that spot and went to look for RodmanÕs group. We found them a bit north of where the other monkey was darted. We saw Rodman masturbating with his foot. At 10:44 all the monkeys started vocalizing very very loud and strong chirps and then we saw a very big eagle (probably a crested or harpy eagle) coming into the subcanopy. The monkeys started vocalizing a lot and moving all around. It seemed like they were moving fast towards the direction that the eagle went. I saw that lots of females were carrying their infants, even the very big infants. These females with infants seemed to be the ones that were vocalizing the most. At 10:50 some of them seemed to have stopped vocalizing but there were still some vocalizing a lot (females with infants). At 10:55 the woollies began to move back to where they were before watching the eagle. When they calmed down a bit, Tony darted another small male. He was darted on the back of his testicles, and he was bleeding a bit. He stayed up resting but not entirely asleep. He was between many branches and very well supported so he didnÕt fall down. He looked groggy but he was moving his arms and was also looking around. At 11:23 we heard the darted male vocalizing loudly (loud chirps), and others that were closes responded. At 11:24 he pooped runny poop (diarrhea-like). At this point he sat down and was looking around. He started moving again around 12:05 and seemed to be fine and moving fast. He moved in the direction where we were hearing woolly monkey vocalizations. Then he rested again in a tree and stayed vocalizing (chirps) but without moving almost until 12:30, and around 13:00 he reunites with his group. At 14:10 we saw a big female approaching to proximity (P2) form the male that was darted (presenting herself to him?). At 14:17 Tony darted a female woolly monkey from the same group. It is the female with the crooked middle finger on her left hand. The female didnÕt fall but she remained held only by her tail for a long while and then she sat down. It seems like this female has a juvenile female who stayed close to her when she was darted. At 14:36 the juvenile female came in contact with the darted females and the juvenile began grooming her. After grooming, the juvenile stayed close in contact or proximity with the female. The juvenile seemed to be solo playing next to the female while she was still groggy. We could see the juvenile spinning around while hanging only by her tail. After she began to move, the female began to vomit. However, she seemed to be moving fine. Tony stayed with her a bit and I went with Kelsey to try and pick up some more poop samples. We left them at 16:30 near Line 9-400."OS17023		Laura Abondano	6/10/13	1/0/00								GPS PP10	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 10, 2013 Ð OS17023

Today Kelsey and I went very early in the morning to do MaxÕs morning activity data on the woollies from group Lagothrix G who we left sleeping last night near the canopy walkway. We arrived there at 5:11am and they were still sleeping. Around 6:40 Kelsey listened for Clash and was able to get his signal, although it was pretty far away (full gain no bars, around 210 degrees). By 7:10, GaelÕs group had moved over to the canopy walkway stairs. Every time we listened ClashÕs signal it seemed like it kept moving closer and closer to where we were (for details see KelseyÕs daily summary). They ate for a long while from the Ficus LL-13-003 near the Tower. In the feeding tree we saw an adult female approaching a juvenile female and the juvenile started screeching very loud, but the female who approached didnÕt seem to have done anything to the juvenile, she just moved close to her. Outside the feeding tree I saw a female that appeared to be doing a chest rub. I also saw a big juvenile or subadult male having an erection. Around 11:30am we heard both signals (GaelÕs and ClashÕs) very very close to where we were (near the tower). At 12:06 they started to travel at 40 degrees and suddenly they all started chirping and running in the opposite direction from where they were moving (220 degrees). Kelsey checked Gael and ClashÕs signals and she could hear both without the antenna. It seemed to be like an intergroup encounter, but the chirping didnÕt last much (only when some of the individuals started to travel back) and then they were all traveling together. It even seemed that Gael and Clash were in the same tree, and there were no loud screeching or upset vocalizations. At 13:01 we saw Gael and Clash traveling less than 50 meters apart from each other. I started following Clash and Kelsey stayed with Gael. It seemed like Clash and the BAM from group C were following Gael. Clash was responding to GaelÕs chirps and vice versa. It seemed that most of GaelÕs group were moving ahead and Gael, the BAM from ClashÕs group, Clash and another female stayed behind (and traveling in that order). At 14:00 I couldnÕt see Gael but when I whooped at Kelsey she replied. At this time I saw the BAM from ClashÕs group to start moving back to where we came from (130 degrees). At 14:04 both Kelsey and I hear long trills with more of a shriek and more amplitude than other chirps. Clash started the trills at 14:03 and the big male replied, as well as someone else from northwest (Gael?). At 14:25 I whooped to Kelsey and she didnÕt reply back. At this time Clash started to move east. I saw him doing a genital rub on a branch. He seemed to be traveling alone and vocalizing a lot and looking around too, but there were no replies. At 14:37 he went to the Ficus LL-13-003 and ate a while. At 14:44 I arrived to the tower with Clash and I heard other chirps very close, but Clash didnÕt seem to be going where the chirps were coming from but instead he waited near MP500. Instead, I heard the group moving closer to where Clash was. However, at this time it started to get windy and I couldnÕt see Clash anymore so I couldnÕt tell whether the group went to where he was or if Clash went towards his group (reunited around 15:00). I couldnÕt see him anymore so I started following the rest of the group. They were traveling and resting and around 16:05 they arrived to the Ficus LL-13-005 where they stayed eating for about an hour. It was interesting that I saw them chewing a lot the fruits but they werenÕt swallowing them but instead they spit them out after chewing them a couple of times. At 17:06 I finally saw Clash again, although I think he was moving with the group all the time. Then they moved towards MP1000 where they ate Spondias from the LL-06-051 at 17:20. I left them at 17:35 and they were still eating from the Spondias tree."OS17029		Laura Abondano	6/16/13	1/0/00								GPS PP10	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 16, 2013 Ð OS17029
Today Kelsey and I went to look for GaelÕs group to try and get a better idea of the groupÕs composition. They were close to where Kelsey had left them last night (between Chichico and Matapalo), but on the move towards Matapalo we stopped to listen to ClashÕs signal at 7:25 and could hear him close towards southeast. GaelÕs group was moving very fast and by the time we were able to get a good look at everyone they were foraging from a very large fig tree LL-13-005. A few minutes later, 8:04, I saw Clash feeding from the Ficus. Group C and G were back together again! At 8:24 we heard some quick movements and aggressive vocalizations, immediately after we saw the big male from ClashÕs group exit the tree and pee. Clash also moved out of the foraging tree at 8:26 in the same direction of the BAM and laid down on a branch. Other monkeys continued foraging. Another altercation occurred at 8:49 either within ClashÕs group or between the two groups, could not tell (the members of ClashÕs group seemed to be using the south/south east portion of the tree) and we saw a female exit the tree and urinate. At 8:53 a majority, if not all, of ClashÕs group exited the Ficus in the direction of 140 degrees. At 9:00 Gael and another male smelled the leaves that the female and male had previously urinated on. ClashÕs group stopped about 50 m from the Ficus and we found them resting quietly. At 9:10 we saw an infant approach Clash and crawl into his lap, he held the infant like a mother nursing. He was resting less than a meter from the infantÕs mother (Possibly ClashÕs mother tooÉthey seem to be in association a lot?). I did not see when the infant left, but it was between 9:13 and 9:14. At 10:32 a subadult female approached and groomed the face and top of head of an adult female for 1 minute.  At 11:57 the group(s) started heading north/northeast from the Ficus (toward the tower). We climbed the tower and could watch both groups. By 13:15 GaelÕs group had continued to move north from the tower and were barely audible with telemetry. ClashÕs group stayed at the tower. Office day. Creating and installing forms for woolly monkey data collection."OS17034		Laura Abondano	6/21/13	1/0/00								GPS PP10	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 21, 2013 Ð OS17034
Today we did our first trial run of data collection on Group C. We met up with them at 8:00 AM in the middle of the Chichico loop. We watched them for a bit and when we were getting ready to take data (8:50) it started to rainÉa lot. It rained for nearly 3 hours. At 10:15 the monkeys got restless and started traveling, but it was still raining too hard to really see what they were doing. I could really only get a good luck at the subadult male (Cuzco). We stayed with the monkeys for another hour, but by 11:15 we were soaked and cold and decided to head to the comedor until the rain stopped. Of course, by the time we got there the rain had let up, but we decided to change our clothes and eat our lunch/drink coffee. We headed back out to the monkeys at 13:00 and found them at 14:11 at Matapalo 1000 (we had left them at Chichico 1400). We tried a 1 hour focal on Clash with 1 min sampling points, but it just wasnÕt enough time to record the information while still keeping track of Clash. We lost him only a few minutes after starting the focal and had to abort the focal. We discussed the options and decided that we should try two minutes sampling points with four minute scans of the focal animals nearest neighbors. We decided to do our next focal on Chromeo (BAM) and were fairly successful. We were actually able to witness a pretty neat interaction between Chromeo and Colugo (male I2), where Chromeo carried the infant for few meters on his back and when they sat down the infant climbed on top of ChromeoÕs back/shoulder area and groomed him for nearly 4 minutes. The grooming session ended when ColugoÕs mother (Cora) approached Chromeo to contact, stepped over him, and then Colugo transferred from Chromeo to Cora. Chromeo moved away to proximity (< 1 m), sat for 10 seconds then traveled between trees. We were able to complete the focal on Chromeo with only a few missed sampling points due to Chromeo being out of view. WeÕre getting pretty good at identifying all the individuals (and remembering their names)ÉWe left the group (or at least Coco, Chloe, and Cuzco) sleeping at Matapalo 625 at 18:27."OS17035		Laura Abondano	6/22/13	1/0/00							"17:56 recovery box

Then we went by Matapalo and with the telemetry we got the mortality signal for a titi monkey: Kebec. We looked for it and found the collar but no bones left. Then we went back to Guacamayo, saw some sakis, and then spiders. The subgroup had Poto, Oikamo and Olio. We followed them through the creek between Guacamayo and Lago, they were most probably in a CONSORTSHIP as either Oikamo or Poto would move a little bit and the other would go following. They were going near an area they do not use very often and Tony shot Poto near Lago 225, just by the bridge. He fell and we did all the processing there. We (AL,LA) found the spider monkeys MQ-1 at 10:20 just east of the puma trail P350. When it started to rain we left AnaÕs focal, and then switched to Oikamo (FS17053). Today we (ADF, AL, LA) went to look for Nenki to download the GPS data. We found the spider monkeys (I recognized Oikamo, Olio, but there were at least two or three other females) at 8:07am in AB-10-002 (next to Puma Plot 3-200) eating Matisia, but Nenki wasnÕt there. With the telemetry we heard that he was near, just a few meters away, so we went there and saw him, along with Andreo, Mono and after a bout of VLC Sammy arrived. Tony downloaded GPS data from his collar and I started to do a focal on him (FS17053). They all started heading west of the Puma Plot, and I could hear Nenki was near because of the telemetry, but I couldnÕt see him. Lots of them were going together, but I only could recognize Nenki, Andreo, Oikamo, Olio, and there were at least two females carrying infants, two or three juveniles, and others. Mono and Sammy were probably not there. They went into a ridge where they ate Clarisia for a while (I marked it as AB-11-002, but it could probably have been AB-06-046 - I didnÕt see any tag on it), and then they rested for about 40 minutes. While the adults were resting, juveniles and infants were playing a lot. I saw at least three couples of infants and juveniles playing in different places, not all of them together. They started moving around 12:20 and then I saw Nenki again. I think there was also Poto because I saw a male with a collar that didnÕt look like Nenki. They all moved towards west, and while moving I lost Nenki again. When they stopped again, they went into a scrambled tree where they rested for another 40-50 minutes. Again there were lots of playing amongst juveniles and infants, and there I recognized that Kauo and Kauoka were also there, and I think that Mika, Mali and Maquis also. Oikamo and Olio were still there, as well as Poto and Andreo. Females started to move first, not all at the same time, and the last ones were Andreo, Nenki and an unknown that I couldnÕt see between the lianas in the tree. When Andreo left, Nenki didnÕt follow but instead stayed resting for another 10 minutes. When he started moving, he headed the opposite way from where the rest of the subgroup went, and while he was moving farther I heard a couple of whinnies and a short distance call from the unknown that was left in the tree. Nonetheless, Nenki continued moving the opposite way. He went into the moretal and there he fusioned with at least three females (I think Mika was one of them) and rested another while, but short after they went out of the moretal he fissioned and again was left alone. Today I continued doing recognition of the individuals of MQ-1. I found Nenki (AV17101) in Guacamayo 450 at 6:04am. He was alone, ate some Clarisia fruits (LL-07-121), and when others started to vocalize more or less in Puma PlotÕs direction, he started moving very fast towards there. I lost him 20 minutes later. Then I found at least 3 adult females with their respective juveniles and infants, and some males in Puma Plot 4.5-200. I could recognize Poto, Sammy, Buka, Boa, and I think I saw Andreo or Lucas (had small crown and long anus, but didnÕt have the distinctive face that Lucas always has), and also Mika, Mali, Maquis, Luna, Liana, Lela, and probably Vita and Violeta (although I only saw Vita once). Then they ate Attalea for a few minutes, and when they heard some VLC from East, they started moving rapidly towards that direction. They were clearly heading towards the salt lick. 

SALT LICK:

It was a very sunny day. They got to the salt lick area (the creek before getting closer to the salt lick) at 9:30am. I think there was a FUSION with other individuals, because I think I saw Eva, Evita, Eli, and also Nenki, Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Kauo and Kauoka that I hadnÕt seen before. At 9:45 they went closer to the salt lick area, and today juveniles and infants were not playing much (as they did yesterday). I observed several individuals grooming each other, mainly between related females (AF, JF, IF), from which I could recognize Buka grooming Boa. In the salt lick I also recognized Andreo. In the time they were there, I could only see Mika, Mali, Maquis, Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Nenki, Andreo, and I think Eva, Ergie and Eli also. A large group of squirrel monkeys passed by, and the spider monkey adults were very vigilant. Around 11:00, though the day was very sunny, it was very windy. At 11:36 I noticed a female (a small adult or a big juvenile) climbing down in the opposite side of the salt lick. She was very vigilant. At first she defecated, and then started to do lots of branch movements. I tried not to look her too much since I was very close, though the branch movements were done mainly while she looked to the salt lick and not when she was watching me. Nonetheless, every time she moved a couple of meters closer to the salt lick, she made branch movements towards me. At 11:42 she went up again. At this point juveniles and infants were playing much more than previously. At 11:46 I heard some loud squeals, but I couldnÕt see from whom they were coming. At 11:53 an adults (I couldnÕt recognize her Ð small crown) went closer to the salt lick, but when juveniles did a lot of noise while playing, he/she went up again. At 12:11 Kauo and Kauoka went near the salt lick (also on the opposite side of where the SL is). Kauo, at soon as she goes down, she only waits a couple of seconds and goes up again. Kauoka waits another while about 5 meters away from where Kauo was, and then she follows slowly her mother up into the tree; but as Kauoka was following, another female (or subadult female?) moved rapidly towards Kauoka and scares her, making her go down the lianas towards the ground. The AF/SAF (dark crown, with a small widowÕs peak, a bit pale pink on mouth and nose, without dot on clitoris) waits on a branch, and then Kauoka goes back to her and makes contact (Kauoka gives a soft touch over the AF/SAFÕs shoulder). Then Kauoka goes up into the canopy again. At 12:32 I hear that they start leaving the salt lick area, without going down to eat. Nonetheless, at 12:40 an adult female comes back (perhaps Eva or Luna?) and rests vigilant for about 5 minutes and then climbs up the tree and leaves. After this I hear that others start coming back to the salt lick area. Another female (not sure of her age) climbs down and looks at me very vigilant, making VWHs every time she looked at me. I was very close to her. After 5 minutes or so she goes back into the canopy. At 13:43 they start leaving the salt lick. I waited a while just in case they came back, but I heard some loud squeals coming from the creek. At 13:45 there was no one left in the salt lick area. I tried to follow them after that but I lost them.

Then I went trough Puma Trail, and at 15:00 found an AF, a big JF and a small JF. I think it was Luna, Liana and Lela coming from south of Puma Trail moving towards the 6th line of Puma Plot. They ate for a while on Solanum and then continued moving towards Puma Plot where I left them at 15:20. 

I went back to camp to arrange stuff before Andres left."OS17064		Laura Abondano	1/21/11								Palm data from the 14th to the 22nd erased.	GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"January 21, 2011

They stayed there for about and hour or two, and when they left I didnÕt see her again.

COPULATION:

They were surrounded by Chorongos moving near, and sometime Nipa was also very close to them, almost in contact in solo-play or MWI, during the copulation. While they were copulating, Nipa moved several times along the branch, and Mono kept stuck to her while she was moving a couple of meters. Also, during copulation Mono touched his testicles once. It lasted 14 minutes since I first saw them. When they finished I saw Nipa rubbing her genitals to a tree branch for about a minute. I couldnÕt see Mono after the copulation.

They started to move away from the salt lick area, moving rapidly towards east and then they went into the Puma plot and started to move a lot through Line 0, and then moved a little bit NW.  They all continued moving, and around line 3-200, at 9:00, there was a fusion with Luna, Liana and Lela. Then they moved a little bit more to NW and they ate a while of Lauraceae and then rested in that tree for about one hour. 

There were a lot of SOCIAL INTERACTIONS while they were resting:
-	Nenki was playing a lot with the juveniles, specifically with Ayax, Ergie and Aisha.
-	Ayax and Aisha played over Lucas.
-	Sammy and Lucas were resting in contact for a short while.
-	Sammy, Lucas and Nenki were resting very close to each other, about 3 or 4 meters between them.
-	The juveniles kept playing over the adult males, and they moved to another site to rest. We could notice then that Nenki was in contact with Lela while resting. Lela seemed to be solo playing while Nenki was resting, and apparently she started to ÒplayÓ by touching NenkiÕs testicles. It looked like it was some sort of MASTURBATION since he started to have an erection and I saw some liquid (looked like sperm) coming out of his penis. While he had the erection, Lela continued ÒplayingÓ, touching NenkiÕs testicles and penis, pulling it several times, and Nenki just kept resting. At some point, Liana joined Lela, and she was also pulling NenkiÕs penis, like if they were playing. Apparently they were pulling too hard, and Nenki changed its position, and then he started to play with Liana and Lela.
-	Nenki played with Lela and Liana.
-	Nenki rested in proximity of 1 meter with Luna.
While they were resting, or before (before 9:30), there was a fusion with Sammy, Mono and Poto; and Nipa apparently left the subgroup. Therefore, we stayed with Luna, Eva, Evita, Ana, Oikamo, and all the males. They started to move more the northwest very quickly without stopping. They crossed Maquisapa trail around 12:30, and at some point we didnÕt see Ana anymore. They continued moving very fast, northwest of Maquisapa trail, moving outside of the trail system. We followed them since we thought that it couldÕve been a BOUNDARY PATROL with MQ-3Õs territory. Therefore, we were expecting that at some point the males fissioned and left the females behind, but instead, they all kept moving very close to each other, and even sometimes the females were leading the way. Males were moving very close to each other, at a distance of about 5 to 10 meters between them. They kept moving North, and were travelling very low in the canopy, without being aware of us. They werenÕt vocalizing much, and no other VLCs were heard after they started moving far north. 

NEW SALT LICK:

When we were about 1km far north from Maquisapa trail, around 13:50, the monkeys stopped and we saw them resting. They were resting vigilant, looking a lot to the ground, and we also saw Lucas doing displays to us twice. They started to move very low, like going to the ground. We saw them moving almost in the ground, and going up very fast, like when they are in the salt lick. About 15 minutes after we saw that, we saw Eva and Ergie coming up the trees with their faces completely covered with mud, so we could confirm that they were in a NEW SALT LICK! We saw all of them going up with their faces and feet covered with mud. They were there for about an hour. While we were waiting, and seeing them go to the ground, we heard one VLC very far (more or less 400mts) coming from North (probably MQ-3?), but we didnÕt see the monkeys from MQ-1 very aware of it, they just kept going down. 

They left the salt lick at 15:34, and started to go back through the same route they used to get there. Nonetheless, they moved much slower, rested and ate fruits in their way, and were also vocalizing much more, including VWHs and loud VLCs (as if they didnÕt were in another groupÕs territory). This is why then we though it probably wasnÕt a boundary patrol, but instead their target was mainly the salt lick. They arrived back to Maquisapa trail, MS 2100, around 17:45, and we left them there since we were very far away from camp."OS17114		Laura Abondano	3/12/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"March 12, 2011

At the end, around 15:50, they started to move like leaving the salt lick, and we saw Sammy and Andreo going near the salt lick. At 16:00, there was no one left inside the salt lick area.

SALT LICK:

I arrived at 10:50, and at 11am I heard some movement inside the salt lick area. I saw Sofia, Silvi and Summer were resting. At 12:40 there was a fusion with Sammy and Nenki. As soon as the males went into the salt lick area, they all started being very vigilant, and seemed like they were starting to organize themselves to attempt to go down and eat from the lick. But at 1pm, when it started raining, they started to leave the salt lick. Outside the salt lick area, I saw woollies, and Silvi was chasing them, like playing. They started moving towards the west, and arrived to the Rodostemonodaphne tree AB-08-078. Nenki was left behind (fission) and when hey arrived to the AB-08-078 I saw Vita and Violeta.  They kept moving towards NW, and it started to rain again. At 14:40 Vita and Sammy left Sofia behind, and then Sammy started moving really fast and fissioned from Vita. BOUNDARY PATROL:

They were moving very fast and very close to each other. They crossed Harpia trail and we realized that they were beginning a boundary patrol in MQ-2«s territory. They travelled all morning eating by the way in several Iriarteas but only for some minutes each. Sara recognized that we were moving through the same area, and the same trees of the time she went to a boundary patrol in Harpia, with Andres and Rob. They rested for about one hour, and when they started moving again, very close to Harpia Trail, they were moving slower but move vigilant than in the morning. They moved along the east part of Harpia trail, and in the afternoon they went back through Q, Chorongo. First Nenki left the subgroup at 16:00, and then we left Lucas near Puma trail 175 at 17:00 after they passed by Evita and Elena. Then Poto and Sammy were eating in Rodostemonodaphne near West of Puma and then they went towards Guacamayo where we left the monkeys at 18:00.

Today we went to look for the monkeys on Lago (yesterday some students saw them in the late afternoon). We didnÕt hear any signal from Poto or Nenki until we arrive to the end of Maquisapa. We heard PotoÕs signal coming from the east of Maquisapa (around Maquisapa 3500). We found Poto and Mono at 8:58am, and then they started to move towards the Moretal, where they fusion with Kauo, Kauoka, Kira, Sofia, Silvi and Summer (9:45am). During the fusion we heard aggression vocalizations. We saw that Mono and Poto were involved in the aggression but we could identify whom the aggression was directed to. They were eating Spondias from and then they rested from about 10am to noon. We saw Kauoka in contact and grooming Poto. While they were resting Andreo joined the subgroup (at 10:37am). Right after they started moving, Poto and Kauo fissioned (at 12:30pm) and we stayed with Andreo, Mono, Sofia, Silvi and Summer. They moved towards north, and they stopped again near Puma Plot 4-750. They ate from another Spondias and then some Iriartea, Astrocharium (AB-11-196), and some leaves from the AB-11-195. Sofia, Silvi and Summer were resting near Andreo for about one hour, and then Andreo approached to contact to Mono. While they were resting in contact (while it was raining), Sofia left the subgroup (at 16:00). Mono and Andreo rested for another while, and there was also an embrace from Andreo towards Mono. Then Andreo left Mono (17:00) and started to move back towards the Moretal where he fusion with Kauo, Kauoka, Kira and Poto (17:28). They were eating Mauritia and then Andreo fissioned again from the subgroup (17:55). Today I was preparing to leave, and when I put my right foot in the boot a scorpion stung me (always check your boots!!!). I saw nothing strange happened to me so we went to look for the males near Maquisapa. In the intersection of Maquisapa and Lago we heard PotoÕs signal coming from Lago trail (towards camp), and we found him at 7:53am. He was with Lucas. I saw Lucas eating fruits for a while in the tree LL-09-121, while Poto was eating flowers from the AB-11-197. At 8:22am Vita and Violeta fusion in the subgroup. After eating a little bit more, they rested. At first Poto and Lucas were resting in contact, but then Vita came close and Lucas moved towards her. They were resting in contact for about an hour, and while they were resting Violeta was also in contact, grooming both Vita and Lucas, switching between both. Then a branch fell to the ground and made a loud noise, and Lucas jumped off the tree. They ate again from the LL-09-121 and AB-11-197, and then they rested again. Lucas was most of the time very close to Vita. At 12:40 Lucas and Poto fissioned and moved towards the river, and they stopped in a Spondias tree (AB-11-064) where they ate for a while and then rested, sometimes in proximity. While they were resting Vita and Violeta joined the subgroup again (at 13:49), ate for a while in the AB-11-064 and then rested again in contact with Lucas. Vita was grooming Lucas for a while, and then Violeta was grooming Vita. At one point, Violeta was grooming Vita and Vita moved away to proximity. Lucas took VitaÕs place and presented himself to Violeta, for her to groom him, but Violeta moved to where Vita was and started to groom her mother. They rested for a long while there, and a woolly monkey came to the AB-11-064. Vita and the woolly monkey were eating at the same time. Then, at 15:45, Poto and Lucas fissioned and moved towards Lago trail. While they were moving, Lucas ate new leaves from the AB-11-065 and AB-11-066. Today I went with Jose to put the video camera in the Salt lick far north of Maquisapa trail. When we came back, I started looking for Poto near Maquisapa 3900, but heard no signal from him. In the intersection of Maquisapa with Guacamayo, I heard the signal coming from Guacamayo trail. I found Poto near Guacamayo 2200 (end of Guacamayo loop). He rested there for a long while, and then started moving east. While he was moving he ate some new leaves of lianas, a fruit from lianas (AB-11-081) and then ate some new leaves of a small Melastomataceae tree. Then he rested again, but I had him out of view. I kept hearing his signal very hard and clear, but then the signal started to fade. I tried to look for him but I just kept moving in circles so I left at 16:50 near Guacamayo 1700. While coming back I checked the AB-10-065 and I saw Lucas resting at 17:00."OS17206		Laura Abondano	8/8/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"August 08, 2011 (OS17206)

Today I found Sammy at 8:18 a little bit north of Guacamayo 1600 (approx.). He was eating Matisia flowers (AB-11-094) with Olio. They spent there quite a long while. In all the time I couldnÕt see Oikamo anywhere. There were several VLCs coming from West and both Sammy and Olio were responding. When they started moving, they went towards the direction of the VLCs, and at 9:35 they fusioned with Poto, Lucas, Nipa, Nika, Nina, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Buka and Boa. When they fusioned, Lucas and Sammy aggressed Nipa, making her move quickly down a tree. Then Lucas approached to Nipa and tried to embrace her, but she moved as soon as he approached. Then they remained about one minute in proximity (P1) (Nipa above and Lucas below in a tree), and then they started to move again. They were all moving very close and doing lots of VWHs. They moved towards east, eating new leaves and fruits while they moved. They ate for a long while in a Ficus tree (AB-11-095, pink fruits with white dots), and also from cf. Paullinia fruits (big tree with lots of vines and entangled lianas).  When they finished eating Paullinia I heard someone coming, and lots of VWHs and then I saw Andreo, so it mustÕve been a fusion with him (11:15). I saw Lucas in proximity of Olio and Nika. They all started to move very quick towards east, like going to the salt lick. 

SALT LICK:

They arrived to the salt lick around 11:45, where I heard lots of VWHs and saw some other monkeys (fusion at 11:45). As they were moving inside the salt lick area, I saw that Eva, Ergie, Eli, Luna, Liana, Lela, Nenki and Mono had joined the subgroup. I also saw Howler monkeys moving towards the salt lick. As soon as they went into the salt lick, I saw Olio sitting in a very low branch, as he was starting to organize to attempt to go down (12:16), and then Ergie and Buka also started to sit very low and vigilant all the time. About a half an hour later, Nika also went very low and remained vigilant in proximity with Ergie. Meanwhile, Lela and Boa were playing. I saw Ergie in contact with Nika, and while in contact, Ergie was grooming Nika. Around 13:00 Buka approaches to the salt lick and about half an hour later, she goes inside. When Buka went inside, Boa remained outside eating from the walls (Boa is still carried by Buka, but she is moving alone a lot!). While organizing themselves, I saw Eli going very low and close to the salt lick, all by herself, without Eva or Ergie near. Afterwards, Kauoka went down (without Kauo close to her). In general, Buka and many of the juveniles started to go down first. The first male to attempt to go down was Lucas (at 13:32), but he didnÕt. Then, at 13:35 Poto went down, then Olio, then Kauo, then Lucas went in, then Sammy, and then they all start to go in and out very fast and I couldnÕt keep track of all. An interesting behavior was that I saw Poto going out with a large block of clay, and when he was eating it, Lucas approaches to him (before Lucas went inside of the salt lick for the 1st time), and they both start sharing the piece, both eating from it at the same time. Then Lucas went into the salt lick. Then a JF (I think Nika but I am not sure) approached to Poto and tried to grab a piece from PotoÕs block of clay, but he didnÕt share it with her. Nika grabbed clay from the ground, not from inside the lick. After they all seemed to have gone inside the salt lick, they all remained moving around the area, and still some of them were going down to the lick again. While they were around, I saw Olio in contact and grooming Nenki. At the end, it seemed like some of the females were going inside the salt lick by turns: when one came out, the other one went in, and they waited outside until the other female went out, to go in again. The last one to leave the salt lick was Ergie. They left after 14:30. 

Outside the salt lick, they were all moving towards Puma trail. I saw Sammy eating some new leaves, and also rubbing his chest with his hand (a repeated movement where he lick his hand and then rubs his chest). Then they kept moving north, but I couldnÕt see Sammy again. I waited to see if he was one of the last ones, but couldnÕt see him. At 15:30 there was a fission and I remained only with Luna, Liana and Lela. Some were moving towards Puma Plot (North) and others towards Guacamayo (West). At 15:50 I left Luna, Liana and Lela. I went back to camp to transcribe all the ad lib data from today, and to organize the subgroup composition. 

During all day long, I saw Olio all the time (since the morning when I found Sammy, until the afternoon outside the salt lick) but never saw Oikamo around. Olio is starting to move alone!"OS17219		Laura Abondano	8/21/11	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"August 21, 2011 (OS17219)

Then she rested for about an hour, and then she started moving north again. While she was moving, a conga ant stung me in my arm and it was hurting really bad. I tried to follow them but it was hurting too much, so I left them a little bit NE of Puma 300 at 16:35. I went back to camp and worked in the lab arranging the subgroup compositions from todayÕs focals and weighting some fruits I collected yesterday."OS17223		Laura Abondano	8/25/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"August 25, 2011 (OS17223)
Today I found the monkeys at 10:35 in the salt lick area. I saw Andreo, Lucas, Sammy, Nenki, Poto, Mono (all the males), Vita and Violeta. They were resting. It rained all night, until today in the morning, around 9am; so in the morning I worked on some fruit weights. About 11:50 I saw Nenki and Olio eating from the Cecropia trees near the hammocks. After lunch I went to the field. I followed NenkiÕs signal and it led me towards the salt lick, but when I arrived there I had no close signal from him. Vita approached him very slowly and cautiously. When she came into contact with Nenki, she gave him her back, and I saw Nenki with his penis out. He then tried to grab her by her back, but every time he tried, she moved. They were moving around Violeta (the three of them in contact) for about 3 minutes (from 15:45 to 15:48) where Nenki was ÒchasingÓ Vita, and she moved every time he grabbed her by her back. They finally started COPULATING at 15:48, and Violeta remained in contact. It was interesting to see that Violeta was nursing from Vita while she was copulating with Nenki. All the time Violeta remained in contact; sometimes resting and sometimes feeding from Vita. The copulation finished at 15:59, and they remained in contact for about a minute. Then Nenki moved and smelled some leaves that were below them. Then he started to move towards west, and he left Vita and Violeta behind (fission at 16:15). He ate more Cecropia fruits from the AB-11-204, and then he ate new leaves as he moved. He arrived to the AB-11-095 and ate some Ficus fruits, and then moved to the AB-06-066 where he ate fruits for a while. He stayed in the AB-06-066 until I left him at 18:05, and it seemed like he was going to sleep there."OS17233		Laura Abondano	9/4/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"September 04, 2011 (OS17233)
Today I went to look for Evita in the AB-10-074, hoping to find Oikamo and Omena afterwards (since I havenÕt seen them for almost two months!). I arrived to the sleep tree at 5:45 but no one was there. I waited a while but I heard no VLCs. Then I went to Chorongo 150 and waited there for another while, until 6:30am, but all I saw were Sakis. Then I kept moving along Chorongo, and waited in the intersection with Q trail until 7:20, but again, I didnÕt hear any vocalization. Then I went to Puma 350 (more or less where I had left Vita and Violeta yesterday before Nenki fissioned), and waited. At 10:05 I heard a very strong vocalization, like if someone had been attacked in the floor (for details see below*), and that moment the spiders started to vocalize alarm (VRB). It was Vita, Violeta, Lucas and Olio. They moved towards Puma trail where they ate some Cecropia fruits, and then started to move towards the salt lick. While moving, I saw Vita and Violeta grooming each other, and them were grooming Lucas. 

SALT LICK:

When they were arriving to the salt lick, there was a fusion with Sammy (at 10:45), and when they went inside the salt lick area, there was another fusion with the other group members that were already inside the salt lick (at 10:49). When I went inside, I could recognize Poto, Nipa, Nika, Nina, Eva, Ergie and Eli. Then, at 10:53 I saw Ana, Aisha and Ayax coming into the salt lick area (fusion). Inside the salt lick I could observe several social behaviors: Violeta, Olio and Sammy were in contact and grooming Lucas; then Olio, Aisha, Violeta and Ayax were playing; Ergie and Ana were playing and grooming each other; Ana and Nipa were in contact and then in proximity while resting; Ergie was in proximity with Evita, Ana and Nipa; Vita in proximity with Ana and Nipa, and in contact with Nipa; and I also saw Elena playing with Lela.  Nika, Aisha and Ergie remained very close to the floor and very vigilant almost all the time, since I went inside the salt lick area (around 10:50). At 13:38 they started to go down and eat from the lick. The 1st one to go down was Nika, and she started to eat from the walls of the outside part of the salt lick. Then she was followed by Violeta (13:42), Nipa (13:43), Ana (13:44), Aisha (13:49), Ayax and Liana (13:50), Evita and Elena (13:53), Olio (13:54), Lucas and Sammy (13:58), Poto (14:06), Vita (14:10), and then they started to leave the salt lick. At 14:20 most of them were close but outside the salt lick area. I went outside and saw most of them, but at 14:46 I saw Mono (fusion) coming really quickly into the salt lick. I followed him inside, and as soon as he went inside, he sat very close to the lick and remained vigilant for a couple of minutes. He went down at 14:57 and stayed there for 3 minutes. When he came out he remained vigilant for about two minutes and there rested out of view in one of the palms near. At that point, there had already been a fission (at 15:00) and the only ones remaining in the salt lick were Mono, Luna, Liana and Lela. They rested for about one hour (RFV) and then went to eat Matisia flowers from the AB-08-138. They ate for about half an hour and them moved towards Puma trail. While moving Mono ate some new leaves and some Cecropia fruits. At 17:05 there was a fusion with others but I couldnÕt identify them. They kept moving towards NE but I left them because I found the dead body of what I had heard this morning (*). At 17:39 I saw an AF, JF, IX and others in the AB-06-089. Some of them were eating fruits, and others were resting. I left them at 17:42. 

* This morning while I was looking for the monkeys in Puma trail, I stopped near Puma 275 where I saw the howler monkeys at 8:44am. Then I kept moving and waited in Puma 350 until more or less 10:00. I saw some branch movements towards south (about 60 meters from the trail), but I couldnÕt see well which species it was (but I think it was the howlers because of the branch movements). I started to walk back in Puma, and when I was in Puma 300, at 10:05, I heard a very loud roar in the floor, about 20 meters south of the trail. As soon as I heard that the howler monkeys started to vocalize about 60 meters south of the trail (where I had seen the branch movements a couple of minutes before); and also the spider monkeys started to vocalize alarm (VRB). That is when I found Vita, Violeta, Olio and Lucas and followed them to the salt lick. In the afternoon, while I was following Mono, I heard the king vultures near and started to feel a very stinking smell near. I tried to follow the smell and I saw the king vultures moving up the branches, just a couple of meters above the floor. I started to look around for the body (that is when I lost my focal) and found the backbone and parts of the mandible. It was a two-toed sloth. I took some hair samples and left him there. I had nothing to pick it up or where to put it, and it still had a lot of flesh so I left it there overnight."OS17234		Laura Abondano	9/5/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"September 05, 2011 (OS17234)

Today I went with two SIT students to look for the monkeys. SALT LICK:

I stood at the entrance of the salt lick area to see who was going in. Then I saw Mono again when he was approaching to the salt lick at 12:38. Then, at 12:55 I saw Andreo and Olio going in, and at 13:12 Sammy and Lucas went in. Then I went inside too. It was very dark and windy, and it looked like it was going to rain. Inside the salt lick, at 13:20, I saw that the howler monkeys were also inside and they were moving very low. When it started raining the howler monkeys began to go down very low and they started to eat from inside the salt lick at 13:48. I saw 3 howlers going inside the salt lick. At 13:55 Nika was moving very low and very close to the lick; she made several attempts to go down while it was raining but every time a howler came out of the lick, she freaked out and moved up to higher branches. At 14:08 Nika went down and grabbed a chunk of clay from the ground Ð not from inside the salt lick (probable one that a howler monkeys had brought out from inside the cave, but he dropped it down to the floor) Ð and began to eat it outside. Then Aisha went close to the lick (14:12), but Violeta went in first very quick without any hesitation (14:14). Then Ana went inside (14:26) followed by Aisha (14:29). Then Eva, Ergie, Eli and Lucas went inside (14:32), and later Evita and Elena went in (14:38). At 14:15 Olio made an attempt to go down. At 14:50 Luna goes inside the lick. At 15:08 seemed like some were leaving the salt lick (fission), and after a while I noticed that only Eva, Ergie, Eli, Olio, Andreo, Mono and Nenki were remaining inside the salt lick area. At 15:16 Mono went inside the salt lick and Andreo followed him at 15:18. Then Eva went inside the salt lick again (15:26) followed by Ergie (15:26). At 15:31 Mono went inside the salt lick again, and the last one I saw to go inside was Andreo at 15:34. Then they started to leave the salt lick.

He was moving very fast and I lost him when a group of woollies and howlers were moving close. Today we went to look for Poto in Maquisapa since Ana left him yesterday around the Moretal at 5pm. Ana was following Andreo and I followed Kauo to try and get a sample from Kauoka. They ate for about half an hour, and then rested nearby. Then they moved into the Laguna area where they ate fruits from some Virola trees and then rested. While resting, I saw Kauoka in contact with a juvenile woolly monkey. It seemed like she was grooming him, but I saw it too quick and IÕm not totally convinced about it. I also saw the new SAF grooming Buka for a while. At some point I also saw Mono with his penis erect. Then they ate for another while and rested again. This time, Kauo was resting in contact with Andreo. Koinka jumped off Kauo and started playing on top of Andreo, hanging from his foot and Andreo seemed to be fine with it. Then Maquis came in contact with Andreo and she started playing with Koinka while she was on top of Andreo. Then Buka came into proximity (P2) with Kauo while they were resting. Then they started to move back to Maquisapa trail and when they arrived there they ate from the AB-06-074 and then rested. We had both Kauo and Andreo resting out of view. Around midday, a group of woollies started to move around but the spiders were vocalizing so we knew they were still there. In the morning we went with Mariano to clear the Laguna trail, since last time we were there it was very closed and we could barely move between the chonta. After that we went to look for Poto around Maquisapa but couldnÕt get his signal. We heard NenkiÕs signal instead, coming from Lago. We found Nenki, Vita and Violeta (CONSORTSHIP?)at 9:30 about 100 meters north of Lago 2050 (approx.). They were eating red flowers from the AB-11-230 (cf. Fabaceae) and stayed there for a while. Violeta ate from the Virola AB-11-231 and then went back to the AB-11-230. Then they rested for a short while. While resting, I saw that Nenki had his penis erected and remained like that almost all the time. Then they moved west. They ate Cecropia fruits from the AB-11-158 for a short while and then arrived to Lago 2100 where they rested for about one hour. Vita and Violeta were resting about 10-15 meters from Nenki. While resting Nenki had his penis erect again, even when he seemed to be sleeping (RPC). While resting, I also saw Violeta grooming Vita and then stayed resting in contact. Then they started moving fast towards east. Nenki ate fruits from the AB-11-232 and then some Cecropia fruits. Vita was moving ahead with Violeta, and Nenki was following them. They started moving very fast and it was windy so I couldnÕt see them. I didnÕt have the telemetry so I began to walk slowly towards east of Lago but I didnÕt see them again. 

When I arrived to Songo Songo, I moved up to the intersection between Guacamayo and Puma, and then moved towards GP. I met with Ana Cristina at 13:20 in Puma 100. She was with Evita, Elena, Nipa, Nika and Nina. They started moving towards the salt lick. I followed them a bit to see if a male fused with them. At 14:00 I left them and went to look for Poto or Nenki. I moved by Guacamayo, Maquisapa and Lago and couldnÕt see them. At 17:00, in LAgo 2225, I heard a slight signal from Nenki coming from NW. At that moment it began to rain and it was very windy so I decided to come back to camp. While moving by Lago, I tried PotoÕs signal several times but never heard it."OS17291		Laura Abondano	11/10/11	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"November 10, 2011 (OS17291)
Today we went by Lago looking for Nenki. We didnÕt find him until 7:55 near Lago 2200. He was again with Vita and Violeta (CONSORTSHIP?).They were eating Ficus fruits from the AB-11-233. Then they rested a while. While resting there was a lot of grooming between Vita and Violeta, and Nenki was always looking towards Vita, but resting about 10 meters away. When they started moving, I collected a fecal sample that is most likely to be from Violeta, but it might be from Vita as well. Then they went to the AB-11-232 where they ate for about half an hour. After feeding, they went near Lago 2100 where they rested for almost half an hour. Vita and Violeta rested in contact and were grooming each other, and Nenki stayed resting about 10-15 meters away. Nenki had his penis erect great part of the day. While resting, we noticed that Vita approached to Nenki and positioned herself in front of him, but right when she approached to him, he left. After resting they moved a little bit towards east, and when they reached Lago 1800 or so, we heard that there were others approaching. As soon as we heard that someone was coming, Nenki, Vita and Violeta started to move very quickly towards south. Then we noticed that Sammy had joined the subgroup (at 11:55). They kept moving south until they got very near to the river, where they rested for a while. Then they started to move north again, and they ate some Pouroma fruits. At this point, at 13:40, Sammy, Vita and Violeta began to move west and Nenki moved east. I followed Nenki mistakenly and when I went to look for Vita (my focal) and Sammy, I couldnÕt find them. I kept looking around, and when I saw a monkey again, it was Nenki. We followed him to see if he joined back with Vita and Sammy, but he moved north to the flooded area so we lost him. Today I went to look for Nenki or Poto by Lago. I was checking the signal but never heard it. Then I went to the AB-06-074 at the entrance of the Laguna trail, and waited a while. I tried the telemetry again and hear only one beep from Poto, but then the telemetry stopped working. I waited a while and Poto passed by the AB-06-074 at 7:30. He was alone and moving very fast towards the Laguna area. I tried to follow him but the Laguna trail is very flooded so I lost him and I couldnÕt move further because of the flood. Then I went back by Guacamayo and met with Ana Cristina. We went by Guacamayo and Lago trying to find Nenki and the others (Nenki was with Lucas, Sammy, Olio and Ana) but couldnÕt find them so we went to the salt lick. 

SALT LICK:

At 12:11 we heard VWHs coming from the salt lick so we went inside. In the salt lick we first saw Eva, Ergie, Eli and Lucas, and howlers were also there. Inside the salt lick area we also saw Sammy, Luna, Liana and Lela. At 12:57 we saw Nenki and at 13:01 we saw Ana, Aisha and Ayax. At 12:59 we saw that an adult female howler monkey was moving very close to the cave, and at 13:05 she went inside to eat. At 13:28 we saw Lucas approaching the salt lick and he was doing several displays to us. Lucas did several attempts to go down, but he was always doing displays to us, and he always moved back up to the canopy. At 13:49 we saw Evita. She was very close to the lick. We saw that she was about to go in, and tried to force Elena to come off of her. Elena didnÕt want to come off but Evita started to push her and bite her until Elena came off of her. Evita jumped closer to the lick, and immediately Elena ran towards her and jumped back on to EvitaÕs back. At 13:51 Eva was the first spider monkey to go down and eat from the salt lick. She was followed by Lucas, Evita and Eli. Then Mono and Lucas went in. They were going down to eat from the lick while it was still raining. Then we saw Ergie, Sammy and Liana going in. Lucas and Eva went in several times, and Lucas always came out with a big chunk of clay in its mouth. The last one to go in was Vita at 14:33. At 14:38, they began to leave the salt lick area; some went towards Puma trail and others towards SE. 

Outside the salt lick, I began to follow Evita. She fissioned soon after they left the salt lick and she started to move towards Sonso Songo. She ate some Cecropia fruits, and also a Lauraceae near SS 125. Then she started to move NW and I lost her when she went into the flooded area at 16:10. I waited since I heard VWHs but I couldnÕt see them, and I was hoping she would come back but she didnÕt."OS17293		Laura Abondano	11/12/11	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"November 12, 2011 (OS17293)

Before arriving to Puma trail there was a fusion with Lucas, Vita abd Violeta at 8:54, and at 9:11 Evita and Elena joined the subgroup. They kept moving east and when they crossed puma trail they began to move south like going towards the salt lick. Vita ate a while from the cf. Guarea AB-11-058. I saw Lucas aggressing Ana with very loud VGR from Lucas and VSQ from Ana. He chased her down a tree trunk and they stayed in proximity (Ana looking towards Lucas) for about 30 second and then continued moving. Then they kept moving south. Nipa arrived to the area outside the salt lick (GP 275) at 9:32 but the rest of them remained closer to Puma trail resting. Before arriving to the salt lick they rested for about an hour. At 10:05 I saw sakis moving inside the salt lick (one male and one female Ð no collar) and heard them for a while but then I stopped hearing them and didnÕt see them when I went inside the salt lick. At 10:30 I saw other spiders moving into the salt lick area but from the northern part of the salt lick (not by GP) so I couldnÕt see who they were (probably Nenki fused at this point because I saw him afterwards inside the salt lick). At 10:20 I heard VWHs from inside the salt lick and then saw Sammy, Eva, Ergie and Eli coming from it (fusion). At 10:33 Nipa moved inside the salt lick area, and at 10:40 I saw Luna, Liana and Lela moving inside the salt lick area. Then the rest moved inside. I went inside the salt lick around 11:00. Inside I saw Ergie, Eli, Ayax and Nika playing. Nika was playing more with Eli and Ayax with Ergie. I also saw Eli and Elena playing while being in contact with Sammy. At 12:40 I saw Liana, Ergie and Aisha moving very low and very vigilant. Right after I saw that Ergie had a chunk of mud and she was eating it (termite soil?... not from the salt lick), and Liana was down trying to eat some of the crumbs that fell from ErgieÕs piece of mud. Then Nika sat in contact with Ergie and looked at her as she wanted to grab a piece of what Ergie was eating, but when she sat next to Ergie, she dropped the piece of mud. They were al moving a lot and very low, but at 13:20 they began to leave the salt lick. When I thought there was no one inside I went out and they were eating some Pouroma from the AB-06-029 and other fruits nearby, and then it seemed like they were going back inside the salt lick. I left them at 13:33 when they were moving again inside the salt lick. I came back to camp to work catching up on some daily maps and daily summaries.

Today Ana C. and I heard NenkiÕs signal early in the morning coming from Matapalo. We followed the signal and found Nenki, Sammy, Eva, Ergie and Eli moving at 5:50 near Matapalo 100. They were wide awake and moving towards north. They ate Pouroma for a while and kept moving. They kept moving north, and while moving, it was almost always Eva first, followed by Sammy and then by Nenki. They crossed the intersection of Chorongo x Matamata x Harpia, and kept moving north. Then they began to move towards the salt lick and when they arrived there they moved through it but kept going. After that they found Lucas, Evita and Elena. They ate from the Matisia AB-09-011 and the Virola AB-09-009. At 8:40 there was a fusion with lots of them: Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Nipa, Nika, Nina, Olio, Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Mika, Mali, Maquis, Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Vita, Violeta, Poto and Andreo. Some ate from tthe Matisia AB-09-011 and others rested. While resting, we saw Kauo in proximity with Eva, then with Sofia, then with Lucas, and then with Sammy. All of them were resting very close to each other, Lucas and Sammy in contact, meanwhile many of the juveniles were playing over them. At that point, we also saw that Lucas embraced Sammy and then they both remained resting in contact most of the time. When they began to move again, they headed towards the Clarisia AB-12-003, where they fused with Luna, Liana and Lela (at 10:00) and then they rested for another while in between the Clarisia and the salt lick. They began to move towards the salt lick at noon. While moving towards the salt lick, we saw that Eva urinated and Ayax went to smell the leaves where EvaÕs urine fell, and right then Poto did the same as Ayax. Before entering the salt lick, Poto and Lucas rested in proximity (SP1) for a short while. Inside the salt lick area, some of them ate from the Sapotaceae AB-12-005 and some others rested around. We saw Buka very anxious to go to eat, since she was the first to go near the branch leading towards the lick, and she was always very low and vigilant attempting to go down. She did this first at 13:39, then at 15:33 and at 15:48 Olio went down close to the lick too. We saw Buka and Lela at the entrance of the cave but they didnÕt dare to go inside. The first one to go in was Olio at 15:52, and then was followed by Mika, Buka, Boa, Sogia, Kauoka, Andreo and Kauo. We saw Sofia coming out of the lick with a big chunk of clay, and Summer approached to her but she didnÕt want to share her clay with him; she was always moving his hands away from the chunk and Summer only licked the crumbs that fell on his hands. She did this twice to Summer. We also saw that Boa always came out of the cave on top of Buka, but outside she moved by herself. Then, at 16:07, we saw Poto, Olio (again), Luna, Sofia (again), Mika, Lela and Vita going inside the salt lick to eat. Then Sofia went in for the third time, always coming out with a very big chunk of clay. At 16:24 we felt that some of them were leaving (Andreo and the west females), and when they left we felt no one else was inside the salt lick area. We never saw Sammy, Lucas, Nenki or the east females going down to eat from the lick. We tried NenkiÕs signal inside the salt lick area, and we couldnÕt hear it. I went out quickly to look for Nenki (my focal), and I followed his signal until I found him around Songo Songo 325. He was with Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Sammy and Lucas, eating and moving north, but they joined again with the rest of the subgroup from the salt lick at 17:45. When they got together again we saw Poto, Nenki, Sammy and Lucas chasing Eva. Then they all kept moving around there, eating from the Matisia AB-09-011, the Clarisia AB-12-003 and the sleeping tree AB-10-064. Lucas, Eva and Nenki ate another while from the Matisia AB-09-011, almost until 18:30, and then they all kept moving around the same area. Today Ana C. and I went to look for the monkeys with telemetry. We first went by Songo Songo but couldnÕt find them, so we tried telemetry in the intersection between Puma and Guacamayo. We heard NenkiÕs signal coming from west. We found him with Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Nipa, Nika, Nina, Evita and Elena, at 8:37 near the Inga cf. gracilis tree AB-12-022. The females stayed eating from the tree but Nenki moved. We couldnÕt see exactly where Nenki went but then he came back to the tree along with Eva, Ergie, Eli, Andreo, Mono, Vita, Violeta, Sammy and Lucas (fusion at 9:20). They ate from the Inga AB-12-022 and the Inga AB-12-025, and meanwhile the juveniles played around and some other adults rested. Then they began to move NW and then north. Ana stayed with Sammy and Eva, and I kept following Nenki, Lucas, Andreo, Mono, Vita, Violeta, Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Evita and Elena (fission at 10:40). They rested for a short while, and meanwhile I saw juveniles playing within groups of woollies, capuchins, and squirrels, and afterwards I saw sakisÉ 5 species of monkeys in one spot!!! Then they kept moving north very fast, and when I saw Nenki again he was near Line 6-200 (Puma plot) with Lucas, Luna and Lela (fission and fusion Ð confusion!!! Ð with Luna at 12:00 (didnÕt see Liana while following Luna). They rested a while and then Nenki, Luna and Lela left Lucas behind (fission at 12:40). They moved a little bit north of Harpia trail where they ate a while from the Virola AB-10-007 and then Nenki began to move very fast towards south. I lost him but found him again with telemetry when he was east of Puma trail 500. He was resting and Luna too. Then they moved a bit south and I didnÕt see Nenki for a couple of minutes but when I saw him again he was COPULATING with Luna. The copulation lasted 12 minutes (from 13:46 to 13:58), and while copulating, Lela moved within the tree about 2-3 meters away from Nenki and Luna. At 13:57 I saw that Nenki was vigilant and that someone else was coming. I saw Ana, Aisha and Ayax approaching while they were still copulating. The ones who arrived were doing VWHs but neither Luna nor Nenki replied back. Then they all began to move towards the salt lick area, and I couldnÕt follow them because there was a VERY big group of white lipped peccaries in between. I went up to GP 400 and the peccaries were still there, so I waited a while for them to leave and caught up with the spiders when they were at the salt lick area at 14:30. At that same time I saw Evita and Elena arriving to the salt lick. Inside the salt lick I saw some of the monkeys eating Matisia form the AB-09-001, and at 14:44 I heard someone else arriving and several VWHs. When I left the salt lick area at 15:20, I saw Eva, Ergie, Eli, Ana, Aisha Ayax, Nipa, Nika and Nina (probably fusion at 14:44 when I heard the VWHs). They went to Songo Songo and I followed them south until they went into the flooded area between Lago and Songo Songo. Nenki kept moving west, closer to Luna and Lela. When Buka came out of the lick, we didnÕt hear them moving or anything. We saw a couple of them resting and then we didnÕt see them, but we thought they mustÕve been resting since we heard no movement at all. Not until 13:28 when we heard some VLCs coming from west, we realized that no one else was inside the salt lick area. (At 13:02 it rained hard but for only 4 minutes so we think the monkeys mustÕve left when it rained because we didnÕt feel them leaving at all). We came out from the salt lick area at 13:35 and Ana C. tried PotoÕs or NenkiÕs signal from GP and then from Puma, but they were gone. We were left with Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Nipa, Nika and Nina who moved towards Guacamayo 825 and then kept moving north. We left them and began moving towards camp, and when we tried the signal in the studentsÕ cabins we heard PotoÕs and NenkiÕs signal coming from east. We found them again at 14:55 near T transect. After the fission in the salt lick (around 13:15) it was Andreo, Lucas, Poto, Nenki, Olio, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Vita and Violeta in the subgroup. When we found them they were resting. When they began to move again, they kept heading south. They ate a while from a Guatteria tree (AB-12-041) and then kept moving south.While moving, we saw Olio self anointing with some leaves, and then Andreo did the same. Then they kept moving. They moved down up to Chichico, where some ate a while from a Jacaratia tree (AB-12-064) and then began to move back north. When they began to move north, Poto and Olio left the subgroup (around 17:15) and the rest went back to Numa trail where they ate a while from a big fruit AB-12-042 and ate new leaves from the AB-10- . While eating from the AB-12-042, I saw that first Nenki was trying to eat from it, trying to open the fruit, and then Andreo displaced Nenki and tried to open the same fruit Nenki was trying before. Andreo opened it and ate from it. Then, when Andreo left the tree, Nenki went in again and ate some fruits. About 18:00 they all began to move towards Chorongo and I left them around Chorongo 150 at 18:35. Some of them were still moving, but I think it were some juveniles."OS17365		Laura Abondano	2/29/12	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"February 29, 2012 (OS17365)

Today Ana C. and I went to look for the monkeys with the telemetry equipment. We heard NenkiÕs signal coming from Guacamayo, so we followed the signal until we arrived to Guacamo 900. Today we had NenkiÕs signal coming from Guacamayo, but close to camp. We found him at 6:10 with Eva, Ergie and Eli, eating from the Virola AB-08-134. Nenki left the feeding tree and remained resting nearby, but meanwhile Eva, Ergie and Eli began to move east. Sara followed Eva and Ana C. and I stayed with Nenki (fission at 6:23). He rested for a while, then ate from the Inga edulis  trees (AB-12-102 and AB-12-111) (AB-12-102) and then he began to move NW by Guacamayo and then by GP, moving across the salt lick until he arrived to Songo Songo where he went into the flooded area. We kept hearing his signal coming from south so we went down to Lago to look for him. In Lago 1475 we saw Andreo, Sammy, Lucas, Poto, Olio, Vita, Violeta and Nenki was also there (fusion around 8:20). I started a focal on Andreo. Some of them were eating Iryanthera from the AB-12-089 and some others were resting nearby. Andreo also ate a short while from a Socratea tree. Then they all began to move west until they arrived to an Inga tree (AB-12-103) where they ate for a while. Then they kept moving west, but Vita and Violeta stayed behind (fission at 9:20).While moving, at some points some of them rested, and in one of these occasions Andreo was playing with Olio and another adult male. They kept moving west until they arrived to Lago 2350 where they began to move south. Unluckily, this is the eastern side of the lake, which was already flooded so we couldnÕt follow the monkeys.

We waited for a while but the signal kept coming from the same direction: the flood! So we decided to go and look for other monkeys. Since it was very bright and sunny, we went to the salt lick area and fortunately we found them (at 12:39). We saw Sofia and Mono with their faces muddy, suggesting they had already gone down to eat from the lick. Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Evita, Elena, Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Summer, Mika, Maquis and Julieta were also there. As soon as we arrived, they began to leave the salt lick area. They began to move north, parallel to Puma trail. While moving, I saw Mono was constantly looking back, while Julieta was following him. Every time Mono moved, Julieta moved after him, and when he stopped to rest or eat, Julieta did too. While moving I saw Mono eating from a couple of Inga trees. Then he kept moving north along with Julieta, and leaving some of the other females behind. They went into a very steep downhill and when I came up I couldnÕt see them. I waited a while but next I only saw howler and woolly monkeys. I waited a while but couldnÕt see either Mono or Julieta. I lost them around 14:50 about 50mts east of Puma 700."OS17390		Laura Abondano	4/3/12	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"April 3, 2012 (OS17390)
