Today Sara, Ana and I went to look for Nenki since last night we checked his signal and it was coming from Chorongo. We found Nenki, Andreo, Sammy, Poto and Mono resting between Chorongo and Matapalo at 7:13 (it rained earlier in the morning). After resting, they began to move towards the end of Chorongo. While moving, Andreo, Poto and Mono ate from an Attalea tree (AB-10-053) and while eating they all remained in P1. When they arrived to Chorongo (the end bit) some of them ate a while from the Virola AB-08-134 and some rested. Mono and Andreo rested in P1 for a short while. Sammy and Poto rested about 4 meters distance. While resting, Eva, Ergie and Eli joined the subgroup at 8:20 and Lucas, Evita and Elena arrived at 9:08. They rested for another while and then began to move towards the salt lick. While moving, some of them ate a while from Inga sp. and meanwhile some of the males rested. While resting, Poto and Sammy rested in P1 for about 8 minutes, and when Sammy left proximity, Lucas approached to Poto and they both remained resting in P1. Then they continued moving towards the salt lick. 

They arrived to the salt lick at 10:36 When they arrived to the salt lick area there was a fusion with Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Luna, Liana, Lela. They rested for a while and at 11:29 others arrived to the salt lick and there was a fusion with Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Sofia, Summer, Mika, Maquis, Vita, Violeta and Olio. When we saw Mika, we noticed that her belly is super big as if she is pregnant!!! Inside the salt lick, I saw Ayax and Nenki playing for a short while, until Ayax left and Nenki remained resting vigilant. Around 11:50 we saw that Sofia and Maquis began to move in the lower branches, and then we saw Ana, Lucas and Olio also moving very low. At 12:17 a small juvenile females (Boa or Elena) was the first one to go inside the salt lick, while Olio was still vigilant in the branch that leads to the salt lick. At 12:21 Olio went inside the lick (12:21, 12:36, 12:56), followed by Sofia (12:21), Lucas (12:21, 12:23, 12:28, 12:39), Eli (12:24), Poto (12:25), Ana (12:25), Buka (12:25), Julieta (12:28, 13:04), Kauo (12:28, without carrying Koinka), Liana (12:28), Sammy (12:31, 12:57, 13:12), Evita (12:31, 12:49, 13:19), Nenki (12:34, 13:19), Kauoka (12:35), Andreo (12:36, 12:50, 13:08), Ergie (12:37), Eva (12:40), Mono (12:42), Luna (12:57, 13:16), and Vita (13:09). After eating, they remained resting inside the salt lick area and while resting we saw howler monkeys inside too (at 13:30). When I first saw the howlers, was when two juveniles or subadults (one male one female) were licking NenkiÕs back which was full of mud stuck to his hair. They licked Nenki for about two minutes while Nenki rested, and then they began to move lower getting closer to the lick. At 14:15 we saw the howler monkeys going down to eat from the salt lick. At 14:27 we saw Mika again in the branch leading to the lick, while the howler monkeys were still going down to eat, and after less than a minute, Mika went inside the lick again. At 14:28 we saw a subadult howler monkey going inside the lick while Mika was still inside. After that, we saw Ana, Ayax, Ergie and Elena moving in lower branches again. At 14:38 the howlers began to leave the salt lick and at 14:49 we saw Kauo going inside the salt lick again (again, without Kauoka). She was followed by Sammy (14:51, 14:57, 15:01) and Olio (14:51, 15:06, 15:10), then Buka (14:52, 15:15), Sofia (14:56), Ergie (14:59), Julieta (15:02, 15:05, 15:06), Poto (15:03, 15:09 Ð after dropping his chunk to the ground Ð ), Eli (15:03), Luna (15:05), Liana (15:06), Ayax (15:10), Ergie (15:13), Andreo (15:14, 15:16), Lucas (15:18), Mika (15:19), and Sofia (15:19). At 15:25, we heard that they were leaving the salt lick. 

We went outside, and some were still around, but some began to move SE while others began to move towards Puma trail. For a moment, I couldnÕt see Sammy (my focal animal) so I switched to Nenki, but about an hour later I saw Sammy again in the Sapotaceae trees near R transect, so I switched back to Sammy. Today Sara and I went to look for MQ-2. We went to Harpia trail 1450 where there is an Iryanthera tree (AB-12-068) and we waited there for a while. We arrived there around 9am and around 9:30 we heard someone defecating in the Iryanthera tree. We saw several spider monkeys that were resting. We saw:

DEMOGRAPHY: 
-	AF (probably WENTAMO): Very dark face, totally black and prominent anus, black dot at the tip of clitoris. 
-	JM (WentamoÕs son): Dark face, a bit of pink on the outer sides of the eyes, hair around mouth is grayish; no dots on anus, a bit prominent. Size between Ayax and Olio. 
-	AF(#2): Large and light coloured forehead patch with an oval-shape in the middle, but also extended sideways. Clitoris and anus without any dots, very pink, prominent anus (similar to EvitaÕs); small body; whitish hair around mouth (similar to Poto); this but well definied sideburns; no pink around eyes.
-	JM (AF#2Õs son): dark face, but very pink nose and mouth (similar to Nika); dark forehead but with a small circled patch at the tip of the mohawk; very thin but defined sideburns; prominent anus without dots. Size similar to Ayax. 
-	JF?: We saw a big juvenile (or small subadult female), with a very bright face, pinkish nose and mouth, with a patch thin half-moon shaped and placed in the very top part of the forehead; and with a black anus with a pink dot at the very tip of the anus.

When they started moving, some ate a short while from the tree AB-12-047 and then kept moving. We followed them a bit east where they rested for about an hour. Today Sara and I went to Chorongo to look for the monkeys because yesterday, after the patrol we lost them around Q and they probably slept around the area. We couldnÕt find them so we went to the Sapotaceae tree AB-12-097 near S 175 and we found them there. We found there Nenki, Lucas, Sammy, Olio, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Vita and Violeta eating fruits in AB-12-097. They were all morning eating and resting in these Sapotaceae trees. While resting, I saw Sammy inspecting leaves after Eva had passed through that part of the tree, and right after, Nenki inspected the same leaves Sammy had. While foraging, Vita approached to Sammy and they rested in P2 for a few minutes. When Sammy was resting again, other spider monkeys were feeding, and while Sammy rested, Lucas and Nenki foraged in proximity P2 of Sammy. Woolly and squirrel monkeys were around the area. While resting, Lucas and Sammy were in contact for a while and then Vita approached to both males and the three of them remained in contact, while Vita groomed Sammy and Lucas simultaneously. Then Sammy left proximity with Olio, and approached to contact with Lucas and Sammy began to groom Lucas. Then Violeta left, but Olio remained grooming Sammy. Ergie, Eli and Violeta were playing most of the time and with woolly several times; one time even Vita played with them and with the woollies. Today we went to look for Nenki and Sammy who were sleeping in Matapalo 100. We arrived there at 5:47 and they were resting but seemed to be active since we heard noises like defecation. At 5:55 they began to move very quickly towards north, moving across Chorongo but about 100 meters north there were a lot of woollies too. It was difficult to follow them and we thought we had lost them (at 6:13) towards Chorongo but we heard some VLC towards R and we found them again. They went to the Sapotaceae trees between S trail and Lago (AB-12-104, AB-12-097, AB-12-118 and AB-12-106) where they were eating most of the time and resting. At 8:55 they began to move towards R trail and we heard some VSQs. There was an UNKNOWN SUBADULT FEMALE who we have never seen before. She was very dark, with very dark face and the anus was black with a pink dot at the tip of it. Today we went to the Sapotaceae trees at 5:50 where we left the monkeys the day before (Nenki, Sammy, Poto, Andreo, Mono, Lucas, Olio, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Vita and Violeta). Today we went to look for the monkeys in the Sapotaceae trees (AB-12-097 and AB-12-118) near R trail. There we found Eva, Ergie and Eli foraging fruits from the AB-12-097 at 6:05. Eva ate a while from the AB-12-097 and then they began to move towards Lago trail where they ate a while from the Sapotaceae AB-12-106 and then they went into the big Ceiba tree near Lago 200 and there they rested a while (mostly resting out f view ). Then they began to move west, crossing Danta and after hearing some VLCs coming from west, Eva began to move towards Songo Songo. When she arrived to SS, she began to move south until she arrived to a feed tree near Lago 1025 and she began to forage new leaves from the AB-12-018. A moment later, we saw other spider monkeys arriving, and saw there was a fusion with Luna, Lela, Vita, Violeta, Evita and Elena at 9:47. There they ate a while from several Inga trees (AB-12-095, LL-08-195) and they ate again new leaves from the AB-12-018. Then they rested for about an hour, and while resting, a female (we suspect it was Evita) was vocalizing a lot of VLCs and VSKs. The juveniles were playing chasing each other between trees. Eva and Luna rested for a while in proximity P1 and P2. Then they ate another while from the Inga trees nearby and then they began to move a bit towards east where they ate from other Inga trees (AB-12-130) and rested for another while. There were lots of woollies foraging from those Inga trees too, and while they rested, the woollies ate fruits. While resting, the juveniles were playing a lot again (Ergie, Eli, Elena, Violeta and Lela). When Luna left the feeding tree, she sat in a nearby tree and when she stood up and began to move again, Eva went to where Luna was sitting and began to smell the spot where Luna sat. Today Sara and I went to look for MQ-2. We first went to the Iryanthera tree near Harpia trail 1450 and waited a while but no one showed up. Then we went towards line 10 in Harpia plot, and in Line 10-400 we went north and waited a while near a tree where we had seen them resting once. At 12:10 we heard some VRBs very close to where we were so we went to look after them.

Demography:
-	AF: face VERY similar to AnaÕs, with a small diamond patch in the middle of her forehead, but very yellow and very bright. Dark face with very while and defined sideburns and become thinner towards the mouth. Small anus without dots, but black under anus. Clitoris without dots.
-	JM: Forehead patch also similar to AnaÕs, a small circle in the middle of the forehead but darker than the AF, and with a vertical line in the middle. Pink around its eyes, but not bright pink but more like ÒfreckledÓ pink. Thin sideburns. Anus a bit out. Body size in between Kauoka and Olio. 
-	SM: Wide patch in forehead: half moon with a slight peak on the bottom part. Thin sideburns, black around eyes but very pink nose and mouth. Very prominent anus and testicles are beginning to be noticeable, but are big for his body size (a bit bigger than Olio). 

About 200 meters north of the plot (Line10-400) they began to move east. While moving, they ate a while form an Iriartea (AB-12-120) and from the AB-12-109. They kept moving west and then began to move SE. They crossed line 10 at around 800 and kept moving south east until they arrived near Line 7-1000. There they rested for about half an hour and then began to move north-east. While moving, they ate from an Oenocarpus (AB-12-110) and from a Jacaratia (AB-12-108) and then kept moving north east, but it was very windy and we lost them. It seemed like it was about to rain so we began to move back towards camp."OS17408		Laura Abondano	4/21/12	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"April 21, 2012 (OS17408)
Today Sara and I went to look for monkeys sleeping in the sleeping tree AB-10-064 near Puma 175. We found Ana, Aisha and Ayax at 6:05. Sara went to look for other monkeys and I stayed with Ana. In the morning while they still were in the sleeping tree, there was a lot of nursing between Ana and Ayax. Ana also groomed Ayax several times, licking AyaxÕs heel which still looks very hurt (open wound of his entire heel, flesh exposed). Ana and Aisha were in contact or proximity P1 most of the time and there was grooming between Ana and Aisha, but mostly from Ana to Aisha. I also saw Ayax grooming Aisha for a short while. They stayed in the sleeping tree until 7:06 and they began to move north. They ate fruits on their way, including an Iriartea where I saw that Aisha was eating, and as soon as Ayax went into the tree, Aisha stopped eating and jumped to another tree and then Ayax began to feed from the Iriartea. They also ate fruits from the AB-12-157 near Puma 500 and there they rested for a while. While resting, Ana nursed Ayax again and Aisha groomed Ana. When Aisha jumped out of the tree AB-12-157, I saw her doing something similar to the self-annointing behavior: she was licking her hand and then rubbing her hand against her chest, but she wasnÕt using any leaves. I also noticed that when Ana jumped out of the AB-12-157, Aisha went in again to feed from the tree (but waited until Ana left before going in again). While resting, Aisha and Ayax also played for a while. After resting, they kept moving north and while moving they ate a short while from an Inga tree (AB-12-158). Then they arrived to Puma 800 where they rested for about an hour. Around 9:45am they began to move back south until they arrived to the salt lick at 11:00am. Inside the salt lick they rested for a while. There was a Taira inside the salt lick feeding fruits from a Duroia tree, and Ayax and Aisha were looking vigilantly towards the Taira (maybe Ana too, but she was out of view). Around 12:30 they began to move towards the south-eastern side of the salt lick but I thought they had stayed around resting. Sara gave up waiting for Ana to fusion with other spiders, so she decided to go and look somewhere else, and when she was around GP150 she saw Ana, Aisha and Ayax so I went there. They rested for a while. Then they ate a while from an Iriartea tree and from the Oenocarpus AS-07-001 and then rested for about another half an hour. Then they ate again from the Iriartea, the Oenocarpus and the Jacaratia AB-08-085. Then they headed back towards the salt lick and passed by it and kept moving by GP towards Puma trail. They arrived to the sleep tree AB-10-064 at 16:40. There Ayax nursed a while from Ana, and then they stayed there, exchanging some grooming between Ana and Aisha, and Ana and Ayax. Today Ana C. and I went again to look for MQ-2. We went by Line 1 towards the salt lick. I called and a short while later we heard a long VHW so we followed it and found an adult male (probably OBE) vocalizing near Line 1-600 at 9:19. He was very vigilant and vocalizing a lot of VLCs and VWH-Ls. He moved around that place, resting vigilant in high canopy trees and kept vocalizing a lot. Around 10am we heard other VLCs coming from NE but very far (about 400mts). The male (OBE) began to move very fast towards north, like moving towards the VLCs we heard before. On his way, I collected a poop sample from OBE, but I only found two Iryanthera seeds with very few poop on them. I tried to scrape the seeds and got something, but then I saw another thing similar to poop and put it in the Falcon. Then I smelled that second thing I put in the tube, and realized it wasnÕt spider monkey poop, but something else (it couldÕve been only mud or dirt, but it had seeds in it so I guess it mustÕve been bird poop, but maybe another monkeyÕs poopÉ but I think the latter is improbable because it didnÕt smell like it), so it might be contaminated. Then he kept moving NE until he arrived near Line 8.5-800 where there was a fusion at 10:25 with another adult male, at least 3 adult females, 2 juvenile males (one big like Olio, another one smaller than Ayax), and one juvenile female. There were lots of woollies around there too. Then they began to move north and when they arrived about 300mts north of Line 10-500, some kept moving NE and others stayed behind towards SW (fission at 11:00). We remained with an adult female (probably Bianka or Apaika) with a big juvenile, who we think are the same ones we saw on April 20th (the ones we have as adult female and subadult male). A small juvenile female, more or less the size of Nika, was with them too. They rested near the AB-12-120 for a while, and while resting, the adult female groomed a bit the juvenile male and they rested in proximity P1 most of the time until they began to move at 11:45. They began to move NE and they began to feed from several Iriartea and Socratea trees (AB-12-159, AB-12-125, AB-12-160). After they ate, they rested  from 12:35 to 13:40, but we had them RFV. We were hearing some VLCs coming from south, but they werenÕt responding back. Around 13:15, we heard a spider monkey approaching and saw it was the juvenile female that was moving, so we began to follow them (we werenÕt sure the female and the juvenile male were still there so we began to follow the juvenile female). The JF was moving very fast towards south, and in 5 minutes she had moved about 300mts but we lost her (fission at 13:15). We went back to where the female and juv. male were and they were just starting to move. They ate a while from another Iriartea tree AB-12-126 and then kept moving a bit SE eating Socratea and Iriartea fruits, and Cecropia leaves on their way until they arrived to an Oenocarpus (AB-12-144) where they ate a while. After eating, they rested from 14:25 to 15:30. Then they began to move back by the same route but it began to rain at 16:10 and we were very far away so we decided to come back to camp. 

DEMOGRAPHY:
-	Adult male (Probably OBE): Wide orange patch, but a bit more diffuse sideways. Dark face without pink around his eyes. Thin but clear sideburns that widen up as they reach towards the mouth (mouth sometimes looks a bit whitish). Not prominent anus, which is mostly black with only the tip of it pink. 
-	Adult female (probably BIANKA or APAIKA): Very bright yellow and centered diamond-shaped patch on forehead (very similar to AnaÕs but much lighter, almost white). Dark face without pink. Very thin sideburns, but very defined. Body is light coloured (similar to Sofia). Anus is prominent, with a small black dot. Clitoris without dots. Skin between anus and clitoris is black. 
-	Big juvenile male (probably BiankaÕs or ApaikaÕs son):Very wide and big patch on forehead, bright yellow. Pink around ayes, pink mouth and pink nose. Clear sideburns. Body size similar to Olio. Anus is very prominent without dots, and has small but dark testicles. 
-	Juvenile female: Very dark face, with only a bit of pink on mouth and nose, and a bit of gray at the sides of the eyes. No patch on forehead, very black, bit a small Mohawk of hair comes out at the top of the forehead. Very thin sideburns. Body size similar to Nika. 
-	Adult female with small juvenile male: Very wide triangle patch on forehead (similar to EvaÕs) and thick sideburns, but I only got a quick glance of her. The juvenile male was small, between Elena and Ayax, and he had very messy hair on forehead, with a dark and diffuse circle patch in the middle. Very pink nose and mouth. 
-	Adult male: wide and yellow patch on forehead. 
-	Adult female."OS17413		Laura Abondano	4/26/12	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"April 26, 2012 (OS17413)

Today I found Sara with the monkeys at 8:05 near Guacamayo 300. She was with Lucas, Nenki, Poto, Mono, Andreo, Olio, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Vita and Violeta. They were resting but soon after I got there they began to move north passing by the salt lick, crossing Puma trail and kept moving north west. While moving, Mono and Lucas stopped a while near GP 200 and they were in proximity and contact for a while. At some point, Lucas approached to Mono and it seemed like Lucas presented to Mono for grooming, but Mono didnÕt groom him and two minutes later Mono left. They began to move north west, and while moving, I saw Lucas chest rubbing in the Virola AB-08-164, but it was more like rubbing his armpit rather than his chest. They kept moving north west until they arrived to the area between Guacamayo and Puma where there was a fusion at 9:18 with Sofia, Summer, Mika and Maquis. The males arrived first and the females came later. I saw Elena and Maquis playing for a while, and Mika was resting in contact with Olio while Olio played with Maquis. After the fusion, they rested a while, but at 9:40 we saw something similar to an aggression: Mika first lunged her arm (""manotea"") to Evita, without touching her, and then Mika lunged herself over to Evita (Olio close to Mika), but it seemed like they fell down a tree trunk and Mika fell lower.  Evita fell but remained on top of Mika. Elena, next to Evita, was also looking down at Mika who remained below in some lianas. Then they all went back up and rested like they were before the aggression. (It seems like Mika was the one who begin the aggression, but then when Evita remained on top, it seemed like Mika was afraid to move up). After they aggression, while resting I saw Poto and Mono resting in proximity P1. Olio and Mika rested in contact while both were in proximity P1 from Mono, and for a short while Julieta went into contact with Mono while resting. Then Julieta approached Poto into contact and she groomed Poto for about a minute. At 10:10 we saw others coming and noticed it was Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Buka and Boa joining the subgroup. They moved a bit north and remained resting for another while. While resting, I saw Kauo resting in proximity P2 with Lucas and Julieta, and then Olio and Kauo also rested in proximity P2. Olio and Summer were resting in proximity P1 while Koinka was playing with Olio. I also saw Koinka playing on top of Lucas. (Koinka is now moving further away from Kauo, but Kauo still carries her in her back while moving between trees). After resting they began to move towards the Ziziphus cinammomus tree (AB-05-015) where they all began to feed and then they rested in that same tree and some trees nearby. While resting, some were eating too. At 12:21 Kauoka was FEFR from the AB-05-015  and Summer came into contact with her. She remained feeding but it seemed like Summer was trying to play with her doing VCK. Kauoka turned back to Summer and showed teeth aggressively (didn't seem like play) and then Summer showed teeth back to Kauoka. Kauoka began to VGR and lunged over Summer, and the Olio, Mono, Kauo and others began to run around and to VGR and Evita, Eva and Vita went down a tree trunk. I saw Evita, Eva and Vita (Evita closer to the tree, Vita closer to the ground and Eva in the middle), coming down a tree trunk of an Iriartea next to the AB-05-015 and then I saw that above them Kauo, Kauoka and Mono are observing Evita, Eva and Vita downwards. It seemed like the females began to go down the tree trunk because they got afraid from all the VGR and running around, but it didn't seem like Mono or Kauo were aggressing them. Olio was close to running around when all got messy and all were VGR. Then Kauoka seemed to aggress Ergie kicking her out of the AB-05-015. Eva, Evita and Vita had left the AB-05-015 before Ergie, right after the ÒaggressionÓ. After the ÒaggressionÓ, Mono and Olio remained resting in proximity P1, and Vita also remained in proximity P1 from Mono. Then Mono moved back towards the AB-05-015 and began to feed again and rested for another while. Then they all began to move towards Guacamayo trail and they moved along Guacamayo more or less from G1375 to G1700. Then they began to move north and while moving some ate a while from the Oenocarpus AB-12-135. They kept moving and Mono ate from a Jacaratia along with Mika and others. Then they kept moving north and around 15:00 it seemed like some of them kept moving north but others remained resting nearby (fission). When the monkeys who remained resting began to move again at 16:00, I didnÕt see Mono (my focal animal) again. We saw that at 15:00 there had been a fission where Mono, Nenki, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Vita and Violeta left. Then, at 16:20 we saw Lucas and Poto moving away from the rest of the subgroup (fission), so we remained with Andreo, Olio, Mika, Maquis, Sofia, Summer, Kauo, kauoka, Koinka, Buka and Boa. Today Sara and I went to look for the monkeys around Guacamayo. Around 6:30, when we were around Guacamayo 1350 we heard some VRBs coming from NW. We began to follow the barks but they stopped. We thought we were near so we waited a while but couldnÕt see them. Then they began to bark again around 8:30 and we followed the barks again. We finally found them near Puma plot Line 6-450 at 9:13. We found Buka and Julieta barking. When we arrived, they kept barking for a while but then Buka stopped and began to feed from an Iriartea. Then Julieta, Buka and Boa began to feed from the Tapirira guianensis AB-12-026. They were there for a while and then we heard some other VRBs coming from SE but very close to us. Julieta began to move towards the barking and then Buka followed. There was a fusion at 9:56 with Sammy, Andreo, Nenki, Lucas, Sofia, Summer, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka. Buka began to eat from the Attalea AB-11-061 and while eating she was in proximity P1 with Julieta and Lucas. After eating, Buka rested and the rest of the subgroup was resting too. Andreo and Nenki rested in contact for a long time. I saw Boa nursing from Buka, and after nursing Buka began to lick her nipples which are still very swollen and hurt (skin around nipples look very hurt and exposed). Then I saw Boa grooming Buka around her nipples and licking the skin around it (definitively not nursing). I also saw Buka solo-grooming her nipples. We also saw Kauoka carrying Boa like an infant for a couple of meters, and then Boa jumped off Kauoka and kept moving. They rested there for about an hour and a half and then began to move back north towards Puma plot. Near Line 6-400 Buka, Boa and Kauoka ate a while from the Guarea AB-12-161 and then rested there for about another hour. Then they began to move south again and while moving Buka ate shortly from the Oenocarpus AB-07-015 and AB-12-094 and then she ate for a long while from the AB-07-007. Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Sofia, Summer, Julieta and Sammy stayed eating in the AB-07-007 but Lucas, Nenki and Andreo left (fission at 14:44) After eating they rested for a while in that same tree until there was a loud chirp from a bird and Buka started to freak out and begin doing lots of VRBs. Sofia, Julieta and others began to bark too. While Barking, Sofia and Sammy were in proximity P2. Then they began to move south east until they arrived to where Lucas, Nenki and Andreo were resting (fusion at 16:10). They were resting near a couple of Tairas who were playing. When I arrived, Sammy approached to the Tairas and kicked them out of the tree, and while doing so, Julieta jumped off the tree too. Buka remained resting in the tree. Sammy and Kauoka were resting in the tree too, and they were in proximity P1 but they also played for a very short while (less than a minute). She began to move again after 20 minutes and began to feed from new leaves, Iriartea and Guarea fruits. She was moving close to Kauo, Kauoka and Koinka, and the rest were moving more towards Guacamayo. Buka went to Guacamayo trail around 17:30 and remained resting out of view close to Guacamayo 1375 where there is the sleeping tree (AB-10-065). Lucas, Sammy, Andreo, nenki and Kauoka were already in the sleep tree. They were resting and I saw Andreo, Sammy and Kauoka resting in proximity to each other. Sammy and Kauoka played very shortly (less than a minute) in the sleep tree. Kauoka was in the sleep tree but Kauo was not (then Kauo jumped off from a tree next to the sleep tree). At 17:50 we saw Lucas jumping off the sleep tree and moving north of Guacamayo, and at 17:55 Nenki jumped off too and began to follow Lucas. At 18:07 Kauo and Buka who were resting nearby began to move and Kauoka jumped off the sleep tree and followed Kauo. We stayed in the sleep tree where Andreo and Sammy remained to see if they were going to stay sleeping there. We left them sleeping at 18:30 when it was completely dark, the moon was out and it was definitively night time."OS17421		Laura Abondano	5/4/12	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"May 4, 2012 (OS17421)

DEMOGRAPHY
- AF: Wentamo? Dark face, no patch on forehead, black anus with pink dot at the end. 
- JM: her son. His face is very dark with a pink nose. His anus was prominent. Size between Ayax and Olio. 
- SF: she had a half moon yellow spot in her forehead with a faded line in the middle, similar than Poto«s mark. She has noticeable sideburns and grey around her eyes. His nose was pig-grey (despigmentado) like Julieta«s colour but darker. Her anus was black. Size a little bit bigger than Julieta.
- AF2: She has an orange half moon with a slight peak on the bottom part (similar than Oikamo but thicker). Her sideburns were faded but thick and like messy at the end near the eyes. She has a long anus and a point not very clear in a lateral part of her clitoris.

Today Marcelo and I went to look for the titi monkeys we thought we had left sleeping near Puma 350. We arrived there at 6:05am and waited until 7:30 but we couldnÕt see or hear them. We started moving on Puma trail and we heard titi vocalizations coming from the east side of Puma trail (between Puma and Harpia trails). We went to where we heard the vocalizations but they stopped calling and we couldnÕt see them. Then we went back towards Puma trail and when we were in Puma X GP we heard the titis calling again from the same direction as before. We ran back but there was a huge clearing in the way so it took us forever to get there trying to go through all the spiny tangles. Of course they stopped calling. But we stopped for a moment to see if they started calling again and we saw the pigmy marmosets (GPSPP10 9:58). After waiting a while and not hearing them call we went back to Puma trail and started walking towards Songo Songo, but in Puma 200 we saw saki monkeys. We think it was DharmaÕs group. We saw an adult male, an adult female and a juvenile (maybe there were others around that we didnÕt see). At 11:29am Marcelo shot the adult male. He ran a few meters and then stayed still. He fell down at 11:32 right on the end of GP transect (next to Puma 175). We were able to grab him with the blanket but he didnÕt fall all the way in the blanket; instead he hit the edge of the blanket and then bounced on the ground. We came back to camp and processed him. At 13:18 we went back to where we captured him and waited until 14:13 to release him. The other members of the group where still there when we went back (around GP 425) and they were vocalizing but not moving much, just staring at us. Before releasing him, while Marcelo was pulling out the blanket covering the recovery box, the saki looked at us and he made a really loud scream. He also looked very awake and his eyes looked very focused, not groggy at all. Then Marcelo opened the recovery box (at 14:13) and the saki ran on the ground until we couldnÕt see him (he ran south). We waited a while but didnÕt see him going up a tree. When I checked his signal (about 10 minutes later) he had already moved 50 meters away from us, in the opposite direction to where we saw him running. When I saw him again (at 14:40) he was moving very low in the canopy and I lost sight of him. Right then it started raining heavily so I waited. When the rain stopped (about 40 minutes later) the monkey had already moved west. I followed his signal and he was moving towards the west side of Puma trail. He moved about 120 meters west of Puma200, and then he stopped. I had a strong signal without the antenna, but couldnÕt see where he was. I waited until 17:00 and he didnÕt move, but I couldnÕt see if he was with the rest of the group or if he stayed alone.

Today I went out to look for titi monkeys with Marcelo and Cecilia. We were walking by Numa and Matapalo but we didnÕt see any titis. At 9:38am we saw Saki monkeys near the intersection between Matapalo and Parahuaco. We saw a big adult male, a smaller adult male and maybe one or two other monkeys around. Marcelo darted the smaller adult male (that might also be a subadult male) at 10:10am. When he was darted we the other monkeys mustÕve left because we didnÕt see them again. The male ran for a bit and then slept in a branch, but he was very lucky and somehow managed to stay in perfect balance in that branch with his tummy pressing the branch (he wasnÕt holding onto any branch and he wasnÕt in a fork eitherÉ just perfect balance!). Marcelo tried to move the branches by swinging on some lianas around the tree, but no matter how hard the tree moved, the monkey wouldnÕt fall down. Marcelo tried darting the monkey again but he missed. We started running out of darts so I had to run back to camp and get some more darts and then run back all the way back to Matapalo 925 (IÕve never ran so fast in the forest!!!). When I got back Marcelo shot the monkey again with a less concentrated dose (Ketamine 50mg/mL). The dart hit a leaf first so it moved its direction a bit and hit the monkey on his left testicle at 11:25am. However, he didnÕt startle or move at all. We waited there and not until 11:46am the monkey fell down. He fell sort of on top of Cecilia and then fell down to the ground. We grabbed him and took him to camp to process him. At camp we processed him as quick as possible. He was already moving slowly and didnÕt seem as groggy (despite being small and being drugged twice!). We took as many measurements as we could but around 12:30 he was moving a lot and curling up when we tried to take measurements. We put him in the recovery box at 12:40. In the recovery box we left him with the thermal blanket since his temperature was a bit low. Then we went back to the field around 14:00 and waited until 14:24 to release him. He was wide awake and looking not groggy when he was released. He ran on a fallen tree and tried to climb up on a tree but slid down. He waited in the fallen tree for a while, and at 14:26 we also saw him grabbing the collar. Then he started moving on the ground and we stopped seeing him. I followed his signal and I finally saw him at 14:45 up in the canopy. He was moving fine but I could tell his movements were not totally normal. He was moving quickly but more taking small jumps rather than running quickly through the branches like sakis do. I felt like he was running trying to escape from me so I preferred not to stress him out so he could find his group. I left him at 14:58 between Chichico and Parahuaco trails.

We saw Rodman, adult female with broken finger, big JF2, AFD with big IF2 and also a smaller JF2 following the AFD. They were feeding a lot from the Astrocharium flowers (LL-13-028) and immature fruits from an Iriartea (LL-13-029) next to the Astrocharium. They arrived there at 9:40 and stayed there until 14:30 (almost 5 hours!!!). They just stayed eating and resting and stayed very close to each other (15-20mts spread). At 12:15 we heard a chirp about 20-50mts coming from NW (260deg), and then at 12:30 we saw an adult male with big cheeks. Around 14:30 they started moving back north. When they started moving we also saw a SF and maybe another AF. They kept moving north. We left them at 15:30 to go and look for monkeys close to camp for MaxÕs activity data tomorrow. We found GaelÕs group at 16:00 in Harpia 200 where we saw Gipmunk and some females that were moving east. We could hear GaelÕs signal so we tried to meet up with him on Matapalo. At 17:15 we saw Gael near Matapalo 400. He was moving together with 2 or 3 adult females, a JF and another JUV. They were also feeding from the LL-09-053. Right when they were about to go to bed (18:20) we Gael inspecting a female (in association with a juvenile, probably the JF) and they began COPULATING. The JUV stayed in P1 and then moved but stayed close while they were copulating. We even saw the juvenile grooming its momÕs head during the copulation. Copulation ended at 18:35 but we werenÕt sure who left who because it was too dark to see."OS17450		Laura Abondano	7/25/13	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"July 25, 2013 Ð OS17450

Around 14:00 they started moving quickly heading south but the batteries from the receiver died (they were fully charged and I didn't put them in until later in the day because I started with the batteries I used yesterday until those died... Something must be wrong with the battery charger). I went back to camp to get new batteries but there were none charged so I took one of the Atelin receivers that were not being used today. I went back to look for the monkeys but I wasn't getting any signal because on the other receivers the best tuning for PIPIAN is actually 150.997! The good thing is I saw a Tayra on my way back. It took me a while to figure out the right frequency so I didn't find the group until 15:11. They were moving south, parallel to Murcielago trail. SALT LICK:
At 12:11 we heard VWHs coming from the salt lick so we went inside. In the salt lick we first saw Eva, Ergie, Eli and Lucas, and also soime howlers. Inside the salt lick area we also saw Sammy, Luna, Liana and Lela. At 12:57 we saw Nenki and at 13:01 we saw Ana, Aisha and Ayax. At 12:59 we saw that an adult female howler monkey was moving very close to the cave, and at 13:05 she went inside to eat. At 13:28 we saw Lucas approaching the salt lick and he was doing several displays to us (shaking branches). Lucas did several attempts to go down, but he was always doing displays to us and looking around, and he always moved back up to the canopy. At 13:49 we saw Evita. She was very close to the lick. We saw that she was about to go in, and tried to force Elena to come off of her. Elena didnÕt want to come off but Evita started to push her and did an open mouth threat,  until Elena came off of her. Evita jumped closer to the lick, and immediately Elena ran towards her and jumped back on to EvitaÕs back. At 13:51 Eva was the first spider monkey to go down and eat from the salt lick. She was followed by Lucas, Evita and Eli. Then Mono and Lucas went in. They were going down to eat from the lick while it was still raining. Then we saw Ergie, Sammy and Liana going in. Lucas and Eva went in several times, and Lucas always came out with a big chunk of clay in its mouth. The last one to go in was Vita at 14:33. At 14:38, they began to leave the salt lick area; some went towards Puma trail and others towards SE. 

Outside the salt lick, I began to follow Luna to see if I could get LelaÕs sample. She fissioned soon after they left the salt lick and she started to move towards the north west. She ate some new leaves, the she ate a spike and she started moving again towards Puma and GP, then she met Ana, Aisha and Ayax. It was pretty dark and windy. Ana, Aisha and Ayax were on the sleep tree by Puma 200 and Luna and her daughters on a tree near by. Ana was resting in contact with Ayax he was hugging Ana. SALT LICK

At 13:57 we saw that Mika was sitting in the branch leading to the salt lick cave, but she went up again after being there for a while very vigilant and aware. Mika, Buka and Sofia were going down to the entrance of the cave a lot, doing several attempts to go down but they always went up again. At 15:03 we saw Julieta going inside the cave and almost immediately going out with a big chunk of clay. She was followed by Sofia, Maquis, Kauo (Koinka ON), Buka, Mika, Kauoka. Sammy dropped his chunk and we saw Julieta going down to the ground to grab the piece Sammy had dropped. Lucas went inside the lick several times too. They went south of L1550 and ate from several Inga edulis trees there (AB-12-035, AB-12-046). While some were eating and others resting.  Lucas and Vita were resting in contact, and Vita was grooming Lucas for a while. They were Òholding feetÓ like a sweet couple in love! It began to get really dark when they began to move back north. They ate from the same Xylopia tree (AB-12-060) (where Nika chased and kicked out a howler monkey from the tree) and the Inga tree (AB-12-044), and also from a Coussapoa tree nearby (AB-12-034). They ate there for a while and then rested. While resting we saw Sammy playing with Aisha, Lela and Violeta for a couple of minutes. Then Sammy remained resting in contact with Lucas for a while, and Sammy groomed Lucas for a while. Here we also saw Vita grooming Aisha, Nipa grooming SammyÕs back, Ana grooming Ayax«s heel. Lucas in PC with Lela and Ayax.After resting for about an hour, they began to move NW until they arrived to the salt lick at 13:30 where they joined Poto, Mika, Maquis and Liana (fusion).

They went out of the lick around 17:30 and some of them began heading south, like towards Songo Songo, I followed them to see if Lucas (my focal) was there but I only saw, Nipa, Nika, Nina and Evita and Elena. Then others moved NW, towards Puma trail and Laura was with them. I left Evita and Nipa at Guacamayo 650 at 18:05.

SALT LICK

SALT LICK:

Around 11:50 we saw that Sofia and Maquis began to move in the lower branches, and then we saw Ana, Lucas and Olio also moving very low. At 12:17 a small juvenile female (Boa or Elena) was the first one to go inside the salt lick, while Olio was still vigilant in the branch that leads to the salt lick. At 12:21 Olio went inside the lick (12:21, 12:36, 12:56), followed by Sofia (12:21), Lucas (12:21, 12:23, 12:28, 12:39), Eli (12:24), Poto (12:25), Ana (12:25), Buka (12:25), Julieta (12:28, 13:04), Kauo (12:28, without carrying Koinka), Liana (12:28), Sammy (12:31, 12:57, 13:12), Evita (12:31, 12:49, 13:19), Nenki (12:34, 13:19), Kauoka (12:35), Andreo (12:36, 12:50, 13:08), Ergie (12:37), Eva (12:40), Mono (12:42), Luna (12:57, 13:16), and Vita (13:09). After eating, they remained resting inside the salt lick area and while resting we saw howler monkeys inside too (at 13:30). When I first saw the howlers, was when two juveniles or subadults (one male one female) were licking NenkiÕs back which was full of mud stuck to his hair. They licked Nenki for about two minutes while Nenki rested, and then they began to move lower getting closer to the lick. At 14:15 we saw the howler monkeys going down to eat from the salt lick. At 14:27 we saw Mika again in the branch leading to the lick, while the howler monkeys were still going down to eat, and after less than a minute, Mika went inside the lick again. At 14:28 we saw a subadult howler monkey going inside the lick while Mika was still inside. After that, we saw Ana, Ayax, Ergie and Elena moving in lower branches again. At 14:38 the howlers began to leave the salt lick and at 14:49 we saw Kauo going inside the salt lick again (again, without Kauoka). They kept going by Guacamayo until Guacamayo 1500 where they fusion with a lot of monkeys at 9:34 and it was very difficult to figure out where each monkey was!. A few minutes later Eva, Ergie, Eli and Julieta joined (15:11). They rested for a while. Lela was in PC with Lucas for a while and she was trying to get him to play.. Lucas was not interested and he moved away. Lela followed him and he did an open mouth threat towards her, she VSQ and moved away. 
A few minutes later they started moving south east, reached the Oenocarpus AB-10-059 were they ate for a while. After eating for some time Lucas moved east and then came back. Mono, Nenki, Andreo and Julieta left the subgroup. Lucas stayed with Luna and Eva for a while, but left them around 16:05 when he left on his own towards East.  He crossed Harpia and ate on the Oenocarpus AB-12-138.  Around there he met again with Nenki, Mono and Andreo (fusion around 16:11). Here we ran into Tony and he went for the darting kit. He met with us around 16:30 and when he got there the males started moving west, crossed Chorongo and ate on the Spondias AB-12-239 for a while. Then they went back south east, Lucas was ahead, he crossed Matapalo and Tony and I let him go to go back to Nenki and the other males (more monkeys, more chances to dart!).. Nenki left Mono and Andreo behind, crossed Matapalo and went towards Numa, he moved around there for a while, rested by the river and then went by Comedor and Numa. We left him around there at 18:33."OS17728		Ana Palma	6/15/12	1/0/00							I forgot to turn on my track on before leaving camp. I realized this at 10:22 on Harpia Plot Line 5-800. The tree was subcanopy with round green fruits the size of large gumballs. Inside the fruit (type: pome)there are a few seeds but not compartmentalized/segmented like an apple(they seem to be in there a bit randomly). Sebastian said the spiders are eating the same thing but he isnÕt able to identify the tree either. The trunk of the tree is dark brown with thicker than normal bark that is somewhat rippled (i.e. the trunk is not smooth and round, but is not fluted either). P.S the nails to tag the trees are way tooooo long and make it impossible to tag them in a timely mannerÉwe actually lost the group because I was teaching Robyn how to tag the tree and it took us almost twenty minutes (first we had to find a rock and then we went through three nails trying to get them in deep enough without the nail bending , we finally gave up and just bent the nail in a U shape anyways). We ended the avistaje at XXXX and reunited with Gael at Harpia 125. He was traveling and calling out for others. We could hear one respond after he began trilling rather frantically. He ended up traveling all the way back to where we started near matapalo, then began traveling back towards Harpia and finally we saw him settle down in a large canopy tree (AB-11-112) with an AF and an AFD with older I1. Luckily, Tony was standing on a slope so I think the male had a pretty soft landing (he was pointing head first and looked like if anything he hit is face while facing down the slope). Since we were really close to Harpia we were able to process him right on the trail (about 10 m south of H1050). He looked good overall, despite missing 2 of his fingers (digits 2 and 3), so we decided to name him Digit (Apparently Diane Fossey named one of her silverbacks Digit because he too was missing fingers). Looks either like a natural deformity (something since birth) or he had them bitten off when he was younger.  We fit Digit with a new radio collar fashioned with light blue tape around the body and a purple circle tag. His collar frequency is 149.800. We paparrazied him for an hour and a half  to two hours, then once he regained ability to move all of his limbs (and tail) we put him in the recovery box. We finally released Digit a little after 17:00 next to the large tree with the figs (LL-14-022). He climbed up a liana a few meters than gently tugged on his collar a few times. He seemed pretty tired (not necessarily drugged, just tired). He managed to climb a few more meters and hang out where the trunk split into two major branches and then finally around  18:00 he moved away from the trunk out about a meter and half and curled up. HeÕll probably sleep there for the night and weÕll go out in the morning to check on him."OS19026		Kelsey Ellis	7/12/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	I stayed in today to work on my Leakey grant. I ran through the forest to locate the monkey emitting the sound and found a whole darn group of monkeys. I was very very confused. Some of them fit the description of P, but then there were just too many, especially of the babies so I really donÕt know if P bumped into G or if Finn and the girls were just really close to G and thatÕs why they stopped, while I kept going and then switched over to G. No se. I followed the group from Q/T past the lab down to the comedor and watched them on their merry way down Numa (thatÕs how I knew it was G). I should mention that before reaching the lab clearing the group did emit a few chirps and seemed somewhat surprised and anxious when they heard some monkey peeps call back to them from the other side of the lab. With no heed, however, those monkeys transcended the lab clearing eating all the miconia their little bellies could handle. After watching them disappear down Numa I was curious to see if any members of P would pop up along Guacamayo or Chorongo. I slowly walked the trails but didnÕt hear anything. Finally, close to Guacamayo/SongoSongo cross I heard some crashes. Again, I tore off through the forest, hoping to reconnect with Finn and my focal. After some serious travel, I thought to myself that these woollies sure are traveling like spider monkeys, and when I could finally get a good view I saw the sandy blond of a spider monkey belly and realized I had been following the wrong primates. Nonetheless I gave a whoop and to my amazement someone actually answered me back. I had been trying Lucy on the radio for decades to no availÉso as I was bushwhacking through some liana and vine tangles I thought again, oh crap I bet IÕm whooping back and forth with Anna and crawling through all this crap to finally get there and see Anna watching some sleeping sakis. I landed straddling the log (and was very happy at that point that I was not a boy ) then bounced off the log onto the ground. Robyn got to see the whole thing and I think it was a good laugh for all. About 10 minutes later I had to save her from stepping on a meter long snake (brownish black with a yellow stripe down its side). They didnÕt move in the fifteen minutes it took us to go around and we were able to pick them up right away. So for the second time ever in following C they traveled through Camp!!! They went from Numa to the comedor then over to the stairs from the muelle to the lab, passed by the lab and then behind the big fig tree and students cabin all the way over to Guacamayo 80ish (where the huge felled tree is). We couldnÕt believe that they traveled so far!!!! A little before 16:00 they started heading back south reversing their travel route. At this time, I saw Celeste grab for some fruits in a liana and then pull back really quickly with an oh shit look in her faceÉI then could see what she was peering at and it was a green tree viper. She still wanted the fruits (or maybe just the snake) and kept trying to grab at the fruits, but the snake was coiled right next to them and she couldnÕt muster enough courage to keep a hold long enough to pull the fruits off. Then Chromeo came over and Celeste stepped aside and he grabbed the leaves that had the fruit (and the snake) at the base and pulled the branches really hardÉwe werenÕt sure if they were trying get the snake to drop or just harassing it or even trying to get the fruitÉChromeo did the whole tug on the leaves/branches really hard but when the snake/fruit did not give he gave upÉthen Chloe came over and started investigating the situation and tried once or twice, but was quickly chased out by Gdubs who then also had a try (Gwen was watching nearbyÉbut you know boys will be boys _). Basically no one got the snake to move or freed the fruits and had to give up entirely. I was able to get some pics of the snake and a video of Chromeo shaking the branches. So like I said before, the group basically reversed their travel route back down to Numa where Robyn and I left them at 16:45 so that we could come back and review and make IDs on the photos I took (all 500 of them, whew).

Sidenote: Robyn saw Cuzco copulate with GwenÉWe also noticed that Coco was following Chromeo a lot, but I never saw any funny business. Also, after the tower we lost Clash, Chai, and Chalupa and didnÕt see them for the rest of the dayÉ Cali, however, was with the majority of the group today."OS19145		Kelsey Ellis	11/29/14	1/0/00								GPS PP10	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"Caught up with C just off of Chichico at the southwest corner of the Chichico loop (after the bridge). Reeder	6/23/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"Kelsey, Lucy, and I traveled to Tiputini today. We took a bus from Quito to Coca via the trans esmeraldes station. The ride took 7 hours. We got into Coca at 5:00 am. We then took a taxi to the hotel mision and slept outside until Miguel picked us up and took us to the environmental office to check in. Then we caught a boat at the dock at 10:00 am up the Napo. It was clear skies until the last 20 minutes when it then began to pour until we got off the boat. We traveled through the oil station and then took a 2 hour bus ride to the Tiputini river. There was another 2 hour boat ride up the Tiputini and then we arrived at TBS at 3:00pm. The moment we entered the comedor we saw some woollyÕs moving in the trees. We then unpacked our bags in our new homes for the next 6 months. ItÕs a very nice station. The offices are simple and stocked. The sleeping rooms have bunkbeds that are too short to fully stretch out. There is a full bathroom in the room which is really nice. Full shower and flush toilet. The comedor is a very large open space and the food has been great so far. The station is fairly empty at the moment, only 2 eating tables are filled in total. But many people will be arriving soon."OS19401		Robyn Reeder	6/24/14	1/0/00							"AFD with I1
AFD with J1
Gael"	GPS PP11	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"I got up at 6:15 and had breakfast at the comedor. Our woolly gang then got our packs all set up and we headed out into the forest around 8:30. HereÕs what goes into a typical day pack: first aid kit, tree tag kit, 2 liters of water, pocketknife, compass, headlamp, extra batteries, binos, food, and a GPS. We walked along the Matapalo trail. We practiced using radio telemetry to find Gael or Clash. At 9:26 we saw Saguinus moving through the trees on Matapalo400. They are two male collared woollyÕs from different groups, but may be related. We caught onto GaelÕs signal and tracked Group G down. We found them close to the Torre, at Matapalo625. At LL-08-034 we heard Callicebus moving through the canopy at 10:34. We climbed up the torre about halfway to get a better look at Group G. I saw one female with a juvenile and another female with an infant. The little ones are absolutely adorable. We walked down the torre trail to follow them and watched one woolly forage in a fig tree for about 20 minutes. After he left we walked back up the torre trail to the Harpia trail. We followed that for a bit in search of Group G. We found them again along the Harpia trail. One female was moving through the canopy and others could be heard further in the distance. At that point it was 11:50, and so we headed back to the comedor for lunch. At 13:15 Lucy and I went back out to the trails to walk the entire Harpia trail. The trail was not well-maintained in some places. Trees had fallen down right in the middle of the path and made visibility difficult. Since I was leading I got many face-fulls of spiderwebs. We saw one AF on Harpia2400 at 10m and 180 degrees at 14:38. She was moving. We saw two more woollyÕs, one was an infant, and the other of unknown sex/age one the Maquisapa trail at 15:17 30m away and at 100 degrees. Infant was vocalizing. It started to pour just as we connected to the Chorongo trail. We high-tailed in back but still got soaked. We returned at 16:00. Lucy and I took showers and then took a nap. We woke up around 18:00 and went to the office so I could finish inputing the last avistaje. That was really hard. You are supposed to say the continuous behavior of the focal animal and then at each 5-minute interval you should say the behavior they are doing the most. The woollyÕs moved and started to forage on fruits at 12:33 at tagged tree LL-06-105. Gael began to chase an UNK F down a canopy tree. There were aggressive noises from both subjects. They foraged for over an hour in the trees. They were foraging on fruits from an UNK tree. At 9:00 Chai and Chilupa were one of the last to leave their foraging tree and I saw that Chilupa was about to poop so we collected a fecal sample from her. But by 9:00 the rest of the group was on the move, 10-15 meters up. At 9:15 they were still on the move and we were following them. We came across a long snake skin next to a log on the Parahuaco trail. At 9:45 they stopped moving and began to forage on fruits in a tree off-trail 15-20 meters up. They were hard to see through the branches. We lost them once they started moving again and didnÕt find them until 10:45 at Chichico 900. They were switching between resting and foraging on small green fruits in the trees 15-20 meters up. They were foraging and resting in this area for over an hour. We clearly saw Coco and the I2 with her, which is a boy who hasnÕt been named yet so we named him Conrad. He is the smallest individual in Group C. We are still not sure if that is Cuzco or Cooper. At 11:45 the group began to move north from Chichico 900. Caluga usually stays fairly close to her but he is a J2 male so he never rides her anymore. Cora was eating and resting vigilantly. They were 20-30 meters up. They curled up on some surprisingly thin branches and seemed to use their tails as a blanket/pillow. One pair, possibly an AFD and her J1/2 could be seen cuddling with each other. It seemed like just as we were leaving another group was meeting up with the group at the tree by the river."OS19409		Robyn Reeder	7/2/14	1/0/00								GPS PP11	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"We left camp and headed in the direction Lucy and I left group G the other day. As we walked down murcielago 300 we could hear howler monkeys calling very loudly in the direction of 140 degrees, around 200 meters away. They sound like the wind against the windows if youÕre inside watching a really bad storm. We went off trail towards the Tiputini and saw our first woollyÕs at 6:45. WE could hear clashÕs signal at 200 degrees with no bars and full gain. Above us was an AFD with an I1 and another unknown individual. We followed them until they crossed a stream at 7:48 to wide for us to cross without a log or something. We took a break to eat breakfast after searching for a way to cross the stream for about 15 minutes. Then we continued looking along the stream until we found a good-sized log to cross. Lucy and Kelsey made it across fine, but when I attempted the cross, I slipped on the first step and slid down the muddy bank to the right of the log, and fell all the way into the stream. I was up to my hips in water. I tried to get out on the same bank but it was really slippery and there was nothing to hold on to so I sucked it up and just waded the stream; I was already soaked anyways. I was worried IÕd step on a sting ray or something but it was fine. I was also initially really worried about my phone because it was in my pocket submerged in water but at least I know now that the waterproof case works really well. As I got out the other side we saw a lone SAM looking at us as he sat in a branch right above the stream. He was probably laughing at me. We started to do a focal on him thinking itÕd be easier to do a focal on a lone woolly. We entered the Harpia plot (line 1) not long after we crossed the stream. On line 1, at 50 meters he joined the rest of the woolly group. We followed them at 9:45 as they moved northwest. I saw an AF with a black collar moving in a subcanopy tree. She also had a light pink, loose-looking clitoris. They stopped to forage in the subcanopy at 9:55. At one point while we were still on some trail in the harpia plot we were following them as they were quickly moving through the trees when they suddenly stopped. Then, although not visible, many woollyÕs, possibly more than 10, were all vocalizing to each other. Most of the vocalization consisted of short, single chirps. This lasted for about 5 minutes and then it got quiet, and the group started to move again. Soon after that we noticed a SAF rubbing her genitalia on every tree branch that she paused at. Possible post-copulation rubbing? We followed them as they moved from the harpia plot in the direction of chorongo. That was absolute shit forest. As we reached a ridge we were following the SAM when we heard larger crashing nearby. A male spider monkey was going in the same direction as our SAM. TheyÕre huge! So much bigger than the woolllyÕs. His wingspan was what took me by surprise most; it was so long. Our SAM must have stopped to hide or went in an unknown direction because after the spider monkey left we couldnÕt find our focal. We lost him at 12:40. At least this was by far the longest focal Lucy and I had done since we got here. As we were taking another break another group of woollyÕs came right over our heads on that same ridge at 13:30. It was most likely group d since they were coming from the north moving through the trees, and there were about 5-6 of them. There was a BAM with big balls in the group. That BAM, or another male, did a display at us by shaking the tree branches in the subcanopy. After our break we followed GaelÕs signal to the west. We came upon a group foraging on spondia high up in an emergent tree at 13:59. This was probably still group d, but Gael was somewhere with them. I spotted an AFD with an I2 moving through the trees. At 14:49 I spotted the collared AFD, this time with an I2. ItÕs amazing to watch them as they move through the trees because most of them use the same route to cross between trees. When they do that you can get a really good count of the group. Kelsey said these are called arboreal highways. ItÕs also fun to watch the motherÕs with their babies crossing between trees because often times the mom will stretch her body across both branches and wait there, essentially creating a bridge, until the baby then crosses over her back. We were following the collared AFD with the I2 until we took out the telemetry to look for Gael when we lost her. We walked down chorongo to find Gael when we came across Toni, Laura and Anna. They were under a tree with a saki monkey. I saw it! It wasnÕt moving at all so it wasnÕt a great look but today was definitely a successfully day of monkey watching. The saki was sleeping on a branch high up in a canopy tree. They usually find their sleeping tree by 2:30 and just stay there all day. Kelsey and I continued down chorongo to find Gael. On murcielago 75 we saw movement in the subcanopy, and it was both a woolly and 2 tamarins moving about. I didnÕt get a good look at the tamarins but they are pretty small and have very high-pitched squeaks, almost like those of a hummingbird. We found Gael in his favorite tree by the tower at 16:53. He was foraging with an AFD and an I2, maybe an older I1. We also saw a muscular BAM with big balls that looked like Gipmunk. They were only there for about 5 minutes when they started moving down the torre trail. Then we left them around 17:30."OS19410		Robyn Reeder	7/3/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"We took a much needed day off. My feet were killing me by the end of yesterday. There was an AFD followed by a JM2, a SAM, another JM1/2, and another AFD. ItÕs really great when they all use the same branches to cross or jump. Arboreal highways. TheyÕre awesome. YouÕre guaranteed to see nearly every member of the group once you find one of those spots. The first time they did it a MAM was in the lead, he had big balls that werenÕt hairy. A juvenile followed him, and then an AF. A few minutes later a SAM came in last. At the top of the ridge I got stung by my first conga. I was moving through some brush and suddenly something stung my finger and by instinct I flicked my hand really hard and heard something fall to the ground. It didnÕt hurt so bad at first and I saw another conga on the branch I was just touching. As I turned around Kelsey told me to leave the spot quickly. She thought I was in a conga nest. Apparently I had another one that was traveling down my arm but she didnÕt tell me because she didnÕt want me to freak out, because then it would probably bite me. Somehow it fell off my arm without an incident. Then the bite started to hurt a lot. I got bit on the tip of my left middle finger. I could feel the venom traveling up my hand and into my wrist. God it hurt. But I never felt sick or felt like throwing up. It just throbbed and then I lost mobility in that finger, and my hand for the most part. I quickly took 3 advil under KelseyÕs advice. It helped tremendously. IÕm writing this at 10:03 and I barely feel it at all. The tip of my finger is numb but it no longer hurts. Maybe I didnÕt get stung that bad because IÕve heard it described as worse. After that we had to follow the group down a very steep hill for which I slid on my butt for the most part. She then moved to jump from the branch she was on down to a palm-frond about 3 meters below and 10 meters across. That may be an exaggeration, I donÕt think IÕm very good at determining distances yet. Anyways, what was interesting is that she took two reeling-back motions before she actually jumped. It looked exactly as a human would do before a jump when someone is amping up before jumping. That must mean that she was judging the distance between her and the branch she was trying to get to, and she had some sense of what sort of momentum she would need to make the jump. I would also make that motion if the distance was a little far and I was nervous about not making it. It was really interesting. We left the group there at 17:10 and went back to camp."OS19417		Robyn Reeder	7/10/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"Today was supposed to be my day off. I went to the puentes in the morning to walk the bridges with Dale and Yamara and the anolis kids. It was really fun. ThereÕs no way that infrastructure would fly in the U.S. but I think the freedom and risk that accompanies less established parts of the world like this is what makes experiences like that even better. I didnÕt see any monkeys but I saw some really cool birds. While we were by the fig tree we saw a toucan in vivid detail because he was so close. They are stunning, almost fake-looking with their yellow chest with thick black bands across it and their huge bills and the green around their eyes. Then in the afternoon Dale and I went for a river float with the Michigan students. The tigres took us about a half hour upriver and then we jumped out and floated down. The kids were annoying but it was a good day to float: the sun was out and the sky was clear. ItÕs amazing to think about how many other species were probably with me in the water that I couldnÕt see. The rivers of the amazon contain the largest biodiversity in the world, and yet I didnÕt see or feel anything! What lurks underneath those murky waters I can only imagine."OS19442		Robyn Reeder	8/4/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"Today is another rest day. Toni and Laura and the Michigan kids left this morning. Now the station is really quiet. We all have the day off and went to lunch and only one table was made. So strange. I love it here. Life is so simple and so simple things make you really happy, like sitting over coffee and talking about convincing the tigres to make chocolate bananas for desert. WeÕre starting to feel like a family, at least to me.  ItÕs a funny thing being stuck with people 24/7 in a remote place: you get really close really quickly because you canÕt hide behind your iphone or disappear to somewhere where no one knows where you are. ItÕs similar to the community I had in running during high school. Doing something hard and something that not many other people in the world do has a way of bringing those individuals together. I guess that should be obvious though. Of course youÕre going to bond with the people that understand what youÕve been through. What I mean is that that experience generates a unique sort of friendship: one that is strong and deep yet because of this career that each of us has chosen the friendship is also temporary, because each of us will travel to different parts of the world for this sort of work. Because of this each of us should strive to live in the present as intensely as we can by working hard and enjoying every second we have in this amazing place."OS19443		Robyn Reeder	8/5/14	1/0/00								GPS PP11	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"Lucy and I went out to find group d after breakfast. They also eventually got up and moved in the direction the other had gone. Then the group moved steadily and kind of quickly south, between harpia and matamata. At one point when they were moving south Delilah stopped suddenly as she spotted the foamy white substance I have often seen on plants lower to the ground. She began stuffing her face with the stuff, which was quite a hilarious scene. I think theyÕre eggs of some sort. She only foraged on them for a minute, and then as she left an AM came over and stuffed his face with them as well. At a later point Delilah also stopped at another tree branch and was clearly eating something from the trunk, but I couldnÕt see it, although I would say it was definitely ants of termites. And at some point when they were resting Darlene approached Delilah and sat in proximity of her, and then Delfin crawled off Delilah and onto Darlene for maybe 30 seconds, and then went back to Delilah. I thought I was following Dahlia and then I noticed the baby was tiny and had no idea where Dahlia was so I had to switch. When we caught up with them they had found a really ripe fruiting fig tree, and were all going crazy in there. They quickly made their way into Chichico, moving steadily. Then I heard many more loud chirps and trills coming from the individuals that were ahead of me in the front of the group. Gordon was passing by in SP1 of Godiva, and when he did Goose hopped off of her and onto Gordon. He continued walking and then stopped and laid down about ten meters away from Godiva. Goose was crawling on him. Then he got up again and moved a little more into a different tree, and then laid down again, and again Goose crawled on him. Goose got off of him and moved about 2 meters away within the tree. Shortly after though Gordon approached him and Goose climbed into his back and began to social ride again. Godiva was within five meters. Gordon carried Goose for a little longer, and I think Goose transferred back to Godiva by 10:37. I was sure it was Gordon because Goodwin had been close by when Goose had first transferred to Gordon. Kelsey noticed an AFD with an If2 on the periphery of the group around this time, and we found out that a few members of HP had been traveling with the group for a little while. We hadnÕt noticed because there had been no unusual vocalizations from the members of group g. By 11:10 the groups had reached line 5 and the members of HP continued moving northeast while G had started to move southeast. They were resting when we left them at 11:45 just below line 5. We had seen almost everyone from the group by the time we left them. IÕm not sure that we definitely saw Gillian and Gizmo. We didnÕt see Gary, Ginny, Gin, Geena, Gemima, or Grammy. But the fourth AFD with an infant may be either Geena or Gemima."OS19560		Robyn Reeder	12/10/14	1/0/00								None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"
We had this grand plan to go to the canopy tower to see the sunrise and then go to the puentes afterwards, but last night it started to storm pretty hard. There was a lot of thunder and lightening, and of course, rain. It was still raining in the morning so we didnÕt go. It rained for most of the morning, so we waited it out and did data entry. We finally decided to go in the afternoon, and luckily it didnÕt rain on us. The lighting was pretty poor for pictures, but it was still beautiful and I finally got to go up to the crowÕs nest! What a view, and what a rush. ItÕs quite high up there. The canopy walkway was a brilliant idea. I saw some woollies by the puentes; they were passing through. IÕm pretty sure I saw Chromeo and Celeste, but they were far away so IÕm not completely sure it was group c."OS19561		Robyn Reeder	12/11/14	1/0/00							Last day! :(	None	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"IÕm still in denial of this whole packing thing. Entonces Tom‡s con su habitual costumbre a echo un Long call y le a respondido un mono como desde Numa o algo as’. Hemos ido hasta all’ pero no hemos podido ver a nadie. Hemos seguido hasta Matapalo peor tampoco hab’a nadie as’ que hemos seguido por Chorongo (la ruta Numa, Matapalo, Chorongo y Q la estaban haciendo algunos individuos estos d’as). Pero no hemos encontrado a nadie hasta que hemos llegado a Guacamayo con GP, all’ estaba Eva con Eli y Emilia. Hemos seguido con ellas y en un momento se nos han perdido pero las hemos vuelto a encontrar por chorongo 700 aproximadamente. Since we left them by the moretal, we took the canoe all the way to Anaconda. We got to MS 3900 and heard them calling from the swamp, we went for them but did not find them. I had a very weak signal for Poto when we were in MS, and we we got to line 6 of the Plot the signal was gone. While we were on the swamp we had no signal, but I guess it was because they were moving towards the plot and were higher.. but no signal in the plot was confusing. Then we went to line 4 and got a weak signal (a bouncing one!)É and we went to line 3 were the signal got stronger and finally we found them on Line 3-550. We had Poto, Mono, Olio, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Vita, Violeta, Buka, Boa, Mika and Maquis. They ate some Dussia and were surrounded by woollies for at least and hour! It was chaos! They rested for a while and here I saw Poto in PC with Sofia and later with Summer, and also PC1 with Sofia. The males started moving ahead, I went with them and Dee stayed with Kauo. Poto and Mono were moving slow between the group of woollies, then rested for a while and then continued moving. Here I saw Mono SA, he picked up some leaves from a tree and chew them with his mouth open and used tiny bits of leaves to rub his chest. He did this for about 40 seconds and then continued moving. They went south, and ate more Dussia and at 11:07 they met (fusion) with Lucas, Nenki, Eva, Eli, Nipa, Nina, Nika, Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Evita and Elena.
Poto ate some Pouroma and moved around the large sub-group. Around 12:30 they started moving south and at 12:50 I not longer saw any males, I still followed the famales hoping the males were ahead or behing.. At 13:15 I pulled out the telemetry and Poto was gone and I had a weak signal for NenkiÉ I followed that signal for a while, but I lost that too.. I thought Poto might have gone back towards the swamp and I went to E to look for them but I got no signal and saw no movement around thereÉ I went all the way to Maquisapa and came back to camp through Lago. No more spiders in the day. 	Entrance to Tiputini. Note to self: for next time, bring copies of UT papers and bring receipts of equipment. I had hard time getting through immigration with all the recording equipment."OS92654		Laura Abondano	6/10/14	1/0/00							"I don't know if the pink receiver is working properly. I hear Sancho signal but Then I point to the same direction and no sinal at all. Also the volume with max gain is very low.
