Orange flagging on trails."	GPS PP7	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 10, 2014 - OS92654
	In the morning I stayed in the lab organizing everything. I installed HanDBase on my iPhone as well as the forms. I also checked which are going to be my numbers which are the following: starting on OS92653, AV24373 and FS26500. I also did tree tags, checked that the telemetry equipment was working and put the 9V batteries to charge. Lago is flooded so I can't go and check on the titis, and it has also been raining all morning and afternoon so I'm waiting for the rain to stop a bit so I can go and check on the sakis. 
	It finally stopped raining around 14:30 so I decided to go and check which collars are still working. I went on Guacamayo up to Puma, checking all the saki frequencies. Couldn't get any signal from Milo, Marcelo or Pipian. I could get a signal from Sancho coming from the area between Guacamayo, Puma and Puma plot. I went north on Puma and Sancho's signal. I didn't follow the signal because I wanted to check on the others. I went down GP checking the frequencies for Milo, Pipian and Marcelo but couldn't hear any. Then I went on Chorongo and Matapalo, checking their signals as well as Gael's and Clash's. I couldn't hear any of the signals until I got to the tower. I went up the tower and could hear Pipian's signal west and Clash's signal south. Unfortunately the batteries (both) died so I could't check Marcelo's or Gael's. 
	The receiver and batteries failed a lot today. The PINK box seems to be having problems picking up the signal, even with fresh batteries. But also the batteries are failing. I left them charging all morning and afternoon and they died 30 and 60 minutes after I left the station."OS92655		Laura Abondano	6/11/14	1/0/00								GPS PP7	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 11, 2014 - OS92655
	In the morning I went to look for Pithecia M. I sat down to have breakfast on the intersection of Chorongo and Q, and right when I finished eating they started moving! I was excited because they no longer have a working radiocollar so it was pure luck! I way Morpho (I don't really know whether it is Morpho but its a large AM), Mona, a second adult female without a radiocollar, a big juvenile female (Marigold?) and a smaller juvenile (Maca?). I didn't see Milo or didn't see a fifth movement with the group. This is interesting because I thought either Marigold or Maca were Milo's... Anyway, I followed them on Q, then T, and then back to Chorongo. They ate a long time froma Naucleopsis tree (I'm not entirely sure but I think what they are eating is the flowers, not the fruit itself). They also stayed resting for about 30 minutes and during that time I saw Morpho grooming the non-collared adult female. He groomed her the entire time, although see groomed him for brief moments... but it was definitely mostly Morpho grooming her. Mona was foraging for insect in the leaves, in the same tree where the other female and Morpho were grooming, and Mona didn't seem to care about them at all. Then they started feeding again. After 2.5 hours following them and checking their demography I decided to go and check other groups. 
	I went to check on Sancho. I found them at 12:00 near Guacamayo 1600. I found their signal a bit north of Guacamayo and waited. They started moving very quickly and very skittish. I saw two monkeys but couldn't identify them. I lost them quickly and ended up following the signal rather than the monkeys most of the time. I was able to see Sancho but noticed that it had no tag or tape (I remember it had a red and blue tape with a gold tag). It is definitely not Dharma because it clearly has the male patches on the forehead. They were moving fast, and then stopping but I could only follow the signal. Every time I saw them they would start moving again very quickly and I would lose them. Also, every time I was able to catch up with them, Sancho and the female would split apart taking opposite directions and then would move very quietly in the top of the trees so it was very hard to follow. The moved towards Puma plot and then east. I left them (Sancho's signal) near Harpia 3350. I think he went into the sleep tree at 16:30 because I didn't see any other movements and his signal was always stronger pointing upwards to the tree. I knew the others were close because I could hear very faint vocalizations. However,  I was only able to see Sancho and a female, but no one else."OS92656		Laura Abondano	6/12/14	1/0/00								GPS PP7	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 12, 2014 - OS92656
	Today was a horrible day. I went to look for Sancho's group that I left sleeping yesterday near Harpia 3350. I woke up very early to be there before they woke up and it started raining (pouring) when I was in Puma 350. I waited there but it didn't stop raining until 7:30. At that moment I decided it would be better to go and check on the other collared monkeys so I went towards Matapalo and Murcielago trying to find Pipan's signal. I couldn't hear anything so I went up the tower. I could hear a very faint signal but it was unclear whether it was coming from north or south. I decided to come to camp and grab the larger antenna and the signal was slightly stronger from Chichico/Parahuaco. I decided to go and look for him but unfortunately when I got there I saw that the forest was totally flooded. Goodbye to plan B which was to check on the titis. I decided to go back and look for Sancho. I found his signal a bit east of Puma 700. I followed his signal until I saw a movement but I wasn't able to see whether it was a saki because there were also toucans,woodpeckers, titis and a huge group of woolly monkeys moving around. It was hectic! I kept following the signal closely and I think they were sleeping in a tree near Puma 900. I was waiting there when I realized I no longer had my fanny pack with me. I went back looking for it, following my steps back with the GPS tracks, but couldn't find it. Then I went back to PumaXGuacamayo where I had lunch but it wasn't there either. I went back to Puma 900 and looked again but no luck. I was very frustrated and sad, and it was starting to rain again so I decided to come back to camp."OS92657		Laura Abondano	6/13/14	1/0/00								GPS PP7	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"June 13, 2014 - OS92657
	Today I went to look for Pithecia M to try and record their vocalizations. I looked around Chorongo, Q, T and Guacamayo but couldn't see them. What I saw and heard all morning were spider monkey vocalizations. The first long calls were in camp, near the students cabins at 6:27 AM. Then I saw a male moving fast from north to south, near Chorongo 625. He was also calling a lot and I could tell others were replying farther away. The day was very sunny, so I am almost sure they were going to the salt lick. Then, in GuacamayoXChorongo I saw Sammy and another male (probably Olio) moving towards GP. I waited a while and then went on Q. I found the sakis near Q 100. I was able to record them but they weren't vocalizing much. All they were doing were contact calls while they were feeding. I got one of the juvenile females to do an aggressive vocalization while looking at me. But other than that it was only contact calls while feeding. They arrived to the intersection of Q and Chorongo and they rested for more than one and a half hours. It started getting very windy so I decided to come to camp and practice some darting skills before the students arrived. 	This morning we went to look for Pithecia M near Chorongo-Q where we had left them sleeping yesterday. We arrived there at 6:11 but the sakis didn't move until 6:39. We thought they had stayed resting there because we saw no movement of monkeys leaving, or any movement at all. However, after waiting for an hour we realized we had lost them. 
	I went to the Naucleopsis near GP 150 to check if the sakis had moved there, but nothing... Then I went to check the PA-14-005 down the hell's staircase in Guacamayo, but again, no sakis. We split up and kept walking around Chorongo, Q, T but couldnÕt see them again."OS92678		Laura Abondano	7/4/14	1/0/00							GPS PP7 used with Ana Pardo. 	This morning I went to look for the sakis (Pithecia M). I looked in the intersection between Q and Chorongo where they usually sleep, then walked on Chorongo, GP, GuacamayoÉ but no sakis around. 
When I was in Guacamayo 225 I saw the woollies, whom I thought might have been Lagothrix D (or maybe P?) so I called Tony on the radio. He told me to follow them. It was a group of an AM (big but it didnÕt have very hairy balls, it had medium sized jowls and it had no radiocollar), AF, JM2, SF, AF, JF2, and SM. They ate new leaves from a Ficus tree for about 30 minutes and then they rested in the same tree. I noticed that the SF was sleeping in proximity with the AD that is in association with the JF2. At 10:35 they started moving towards camp. It was interesting that the first one to move was the AM (while the rest were s leeping), and once after he started moving the SM followed and then the others started waking up and following the AM and SM. Kelsey and Tony arrived to where I was near the Paullinia (LL-14-034) where they ate fruits for a while.  We saw an aggression in the feeding tree where it seemed like an adult was chasing a subadult (unknown sex), and this happened with a lot of ÒscreamingÓ vocalizations. IÕm not sure whether the subadult was kicked out of the tree, but I think it stayed feeding there after the aggression. After feeding they kept moving towards camp but when they got to the big Ficus tree next to the lab and we lost them around 11:20. We looked for a while but couldnÕt find them. We found Lucy who was following Goodwin (?) and some other woolly monkeys. Kelsey and Tony stayed with her and the woollies and I went back to look for sakis.

They rested and when it stopped raining they moved back to W and back to RxS. As they were moving I saw one of the AFs Òback rubbingÓ against the tree trunk of an emergent tree. Then the JF that was following the AF did the same on the same spot. At 17:54 they arrived to the tree AB-13-123 that is an emergent tree where IÕve seem monkeys sleep before. There I saw the same Òback rubbingÓ behavior (Kelsey told me later that they do that after the rain). At 18:05 I left them sleeping in the sleep tree and there were others around that I assume were also sleeping."OS92689		Laura Abondano	7/15/14	1/0/00							Woolly monkey darted.	GPS PP12	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"July 15, 2014 - OS92689
Today I went with Kelsey, Robyn and Lucy to check on the woolly monkeys I left sleeping yesterday. We got there at 6:08. We saw one monkey moving at 6:13 but we couldnÕt see the other.  Lucy and I started following the female that was moving along with a juvenile male, while Kelsey and Robyn stayed behind to check whether the other monkeys were still there or not. The AF and the SM started moving up the ridge that is north of R and then they started moving west in parallel to U trail. The female kept trilling and vocalizing, and near U trail we heard that someone else was approaching. We saw a male that started moving with the female and the juvenile. It wasnÕt a BAM but it was big enough and it had hairy chest. It seemed like they were in some sort of consortship because they moved away from the rest of the group (that Kelsey believes they started moving west around W trail) and around 7:30 they stopped in a tall tree where we couldnÕt see them. Kelsey and Robyn caught up with us and then we waited for about an hour and a half but we couldnÕt see or hear the woollies anymore. We decided to split up and I went with Kelsey towards Danta trail. We found the woollies again near Danta 200. We saw them because there was an AF vocalizing VRB between Danta and Lago. On Danta 200 we saw an AM, and AF with an SM (probably the same ones we were following this morning). We couldnÕt see any others but there were definitely more of them vocalizing west. They started moving west and when we got to Songo Songo we saw an AFD with an IM2 (or JM1?). We kept following the male and at 10:20 and 10:30 Tony tried to dart the male but he missed. I collected a poop sample from this male (ABONDANO-14-002). We kept following the male but around 10:30, when we started to move away from Songo Songo and more towards Guacamayo ~1000 we felt like the rest of the group stayed behind and that we were only following the adult male. Around 11:10 the male found other woollies and they all started chirping ahead of us. WeÕre not sure whether we switched groups Ð form D to P Ð or if they were the same group all along. When we got to Guacamayo 1000 we saw an AFD carrying an IX1, a SF2, and another AM. They started moving towards Puma but while they were moving Tony darted (11:39) one of the adult males (poop sample ABONDANO-14-003 collected right before Tony darted him) very close to Guacamayo 900. He fell down around 11:45 and we ran back to camp to process the monkey. 
At camp Tony, Kelsey and I examined the monkey while Robyn and Lucy helped taking photos and taking notes on the measurements. It was good that we finished all the measurements before he woke up so there was no need to give him a second dose. When we put him in the recovery box he was almost fully asleep, but after a bit we checked and he had already chewed on his collar. Also, during the exam he didnÕt poop, but he pooped all over the recovery box and the monkey was eating his own shit! When Tony tried to open the box to pull out the towel that had poop all over, the monkey immediately grabbed the towel (sort of being possessive about his poop/food? IÕve seen a similar behavior in dogs when they throw up). Tony also collected a poop sample for me to do hormone extraction (ABONDANO-14-004 and SPE column ABONDANO-14-006). The monkey didnÕt seem to like his collar. When we checked on him he was always trying to pull it out. 
At 15:15 the monkey was already fully awake so we decided to go and release him. We took him to the place were he was darted. We released him at 15:54. When Tony opened the box the monkey ran up to a tree and was able to climb up with no problem. He tried to pull out his collar for about 15 minutes. Then he went higher up in the tree and rested for a bit. Then he moved to a different tree (moving normally) and stayed there resting. Tony and I left at 17:38, while Robyn and Lucy stayed checking on him. YAY WOOLLY MONKEY!!! _"OS92690		Laura Abondano	7/16/14	1/0/00							Sakis and Eva. Today I went to look for Kauo to try and collect a poop sample for hormone extraction. I went with the telemetry and the computer and see if I could download the GPS collar data. I checked SanchoÕs signal and it was really strong and pointing in the direction where I had heard the vocalization (so he must've been close to line 3-350 or so). I didn't find anything so ended up walking the first quebrada with water up to my thighs. Then I had to cross a second quebrada on which I had to pull an Indiana jones move. I had to cross a small log that was rotten so half of it broke and I was left in the middle I it sitting down in the middle of the deep quebrada. I had to throw the antenna, my binoculars and my backpack (which had the receiver and the Lenovo computer inside) to the other side of the stream and then I had to climb up a wall from one side of the steam and lift myself up. When I finally crossed the quebradas I had to go through a moretal like area with lots of spiny tangles. 
Anyway, I finally got to where Kauo was at 10:32.  She was resting near line 6-600. I had a very strong signal but couldn't see her or any other spider. All I saw were woollies, resting too in the AB-07-100. At 11:22 I finally saw Kauo resting in the Spondias tree AB-08-353, next to the tree where the woollies were resting. The woollies started moving around 11:30 but the spiders stayed. Then I noticed that another spider was resting in a close by tree. I think it was Taiga (grey face with small and dark triangle patch on forehead, with a small line in the middle Ð similar but not as pointy as WampiÕs in San Juan Ð, pink mouth with grey around and very thin sideburns, clitoris with no black spots and very dangly, anus sticks out a bit). Nenki was also resting around. (SGC: Kauo, Koinka, Kiwi, Taiga and Nenki). At 11:40 they started foraging from the Spondias AB-07-100 and while foraging was when I clearly saw Taiga and Nenki. Kauo ate for a very short time and then laid down again to sleep. While sleeping I was able to see Kiwi. It looks like it could be a boy with a very long, or a girl with a very pale/brown clitoris. I think it is a boy. I also noticed that he was sometimes in lateral position, but still in ventral position sometimes. While Kauo was resting Nenki left the subgroup (fission?) at 12:15, and Taiga also moved a bit but stayed within 30 meters distance. Kauo, Koinka and Kiwi stayed resting. They rested there until almost 13:30 and then they started moving south west a bit closest to the moretal. They ate from a Spondias tree for about an hour, but it was mostly Taiga and Koinka while Kauo rested. After a while Taiga rested and Kauo began to eat fruits while Koinka continued feeding. While Taiga was resting I saw her pooping so I collected her sample for hormone extraction and DNA analysis. When Kauo (finally) pooped at 14:43 I collected her fecal sample and went back to camp to process the samples from both Taiga and Kauo."OS92693		Laura Abondano	7/19/14	1/0/00							Ana. 	Today was saki hunt day. I went to look for Pithecia M. I looked around Q, Chorongo and T. Around 10:00 it started raining hard and I was close to camp so decided to come and pay my bills while it was raining. After the rain I went out again to look for the sakis. I found them at 12:32 near Q75. They were moving north-west, along Guacamayo trail. They got to the Iryanthera PA-14-022 where they ate fruits for a while. I saw the JF vocalizing a lot and pulling hard an Iryanthera fruit that Marigold had in her hands (looks like a corn cob). The JF kept pulling and screeching but Marigold kept pulling back until Marigold finally let go and gave the JF the fruit. Then they kept moving and when they got to ~Guacamayo350 it started really hard again. It was interesting to see that they kept foraging and moving in the rain. While it was raining I could only see Maca (the juvenile female). I saw her robbing food from Morpho (I think it was flowers or an infructescence from a liana). First Morpho grabbed the piece and immediately after the JF came into contact of Morpho. The JF tried to rob MorphoÕs food but he wouldnÕt give any to her. Then the JF started screeching and Morpho ran but the JF would chase him. Finally she got a piece of what Morpho was eating. After the rain they stayed around that area for a while. I saw some of them go up in a tall tree around 15:20 (sleep tree? PA-14-016) but Mona stayed eating some of the fruit/flowers of the corn looking thing. She ate that until almost 16:00 and then went up into the PA-14-016. I stayed there until almost 17:00 and nothing moved. Around 7:00 we saw one monkey scratching, and at 7:17 two of the moved within the sleep tree but stayed there. I was able to see two of them grooming but couldnÕt tell which animals were they. They crossed Chorongo and then went up to Q and then started heading towards camp moving along T trail. Tony tried darting Marigold at 11:17 and then Morpho at 11:45. It seemed like Tony got Morpho because he was checking his tail on the place that Tony darted, but he didnÕt get groggy at all and kept moving normally afterwards. When they arrived to the intersection between Chorongo and Q we saw Morpho eating from a tree that had big brown fruits that have a single large red seed. 	This morning I went out with Ana to get the sakis we left sleeping yesterday afternoon. We arrived to ~Harpia 4225 and checked the tree where we left the saki monkey sleeping yesterday, and it was still there, in the same spot. We waited until it moved, and we noticed it was Marigold. She didnÕt wake up until 6:43. At 6:50 Marigold moved into the adjacent tree and there all of the other individuals started moving so I assume they slept in that tree. They started heading a bit east, just a few meters away from the trail. They ate for about an hour from the PA-14-012, which is a small tree that has very large brown fruits with a single big red seed. Then they moved a bit and rested for a bit longer than an hour. Tony and Alejandra (the vet) arrived while the sakis were resting. After resting they started moving west of the Harpia trail. They ate a bit of the PA-14-013 from which they were foraging seeds (winged seeds). Then they kept moving west. It was really interesting that we stayed following Morpho. He was moving really fast and vocalizing a lot, and we realized that we were only with him and not with the others. We also heard some loud contact calls coming from north-east towards GP trail which we werenÕt sure whether they were from individuals in the same group, or maybe from a different group.  We also heard loud contact calls from south-east, which we assume it mustÕve been Mona and Marigold (and maybe Maca too?). They were vocalizing mostly contact calls and trills. At 11:53 Tony tried darting Morpho but Morpho kept moving normally. They vocalized a lot until finally Morpho met up with another saki individual at 12:13, near GP trail. They rested for a bit and then they started moving towards Chorongo. While moving Tony darted Morpho, at 13:00. He was shot on his right heel. I was able to see that Morpho had blood on his foot, but he never got groggy. He just licked is foot several times and stayed in the same tree for a while, but then kept moving. It seemed like Morpho was trying to put less pressure on his right foot, but after a while he was moving normally. They stopped and foraged at the PA-14-011 where they ate the seeds. Then they kept moving towards Q trail. They ate winged seeds from the PA-11-101 and after that they moved a bit towards camp where we saw Marigold go up into a tree at TIME. Alejandra and I left at 16:30 and we left Ana and Tony with the monkeys.

	Ana left the sakis (Pithecia M) sleeping near the intersection between Chorongo, Puma and Matamata, so we went this morning to look for them (in sleep tree PA-14-015). We checked the spot where Ana had last seen them yesterday, but the monkey she was looking at yesterday was no longer there. We tried seeing around the tree but couldnÕt see any monkey. We finally saw a movement in the tree at 8:45. It was Mona moving out of the tree, but we stayed for a bit and couldnÕt see the others. Mona started moving towards the feeding tree PA-14-012 (big brown fruit, really heavy). When we got to that tree the other sakis were already feeding, so they mustÕve jumped first without us noticing, or maybe they slept in a different tree and we just didnÕt see them. While the monkeys were feeding Tony tried darting Mona, but Tony forgot to load the dart in the rifle so Mona got scared and jumped off the tree. They started moving south east, towards Q trail. They stopped in a tree and they started eating winged seeds (PA-14-016?). It started raining and we were trying to tag the tree, and all of a sudden the monkeys were gone. We couldnÕt see them anymore so we waited but even after it stopped raining they wouldnÕt move. Ana saw them move way ahead so we ran and caught up with them. Then they moved towards Chorongo trail where Mona and Marigold started feeding from the tree PA-14-017? (same fruits as the PA-14-007). While they were feeding (around noon) we could hear Morpho calling from south-east and Mona and Marigold stopped feeding and started heading in MorphoÕs direction. While they were moving Tony shot Marigold at 12:21 with 30mg of Zoletil. We saw her for a second but then we lost her out of sight. She finally fell down and hit the ground from ~12 meters high @ 12:29. When she fell down she seemed to be pretty awake. She tried grabbing some branches with her hands but most of her lower limbs wouldnÕt move. We came back to camp to process Marigold. She seemed to be pretty awake most of the time so Tony had to give her some extra Ketamine. We finished processing around 14:30 and then we left her in the recovery box until ~15:40. We released at 16:09 in the same spot where we darted her. As soon as Tony opened the recovery box she came out and climbed up a tree with no problem. She also did several twitter vocalizations but we couldnÕt hear any response. Then she went up into a very tall tree and we couldnÕt see her anymore. We waited until 17:20 and she didnÕt move again, so she probably stayed sleeping there."OS92699		Laura Abondano	7/25/14	1/0/00								GPS PP12	FALSE	FALSE		FALSE	"July 25, 2014 - OS92699
	This morning I went out to check on Marigold with some students from Tony and AndresÕ course. At 7:50am Marigold was still sleeping in the tree where we left her yesterday. We couldnÕt hear anyone replying to her vocalizations. At 8:18 she vocalized a twitter call and then at 8:19 we finally saw her moving within the tree. She jumped off the tree at 8:20 and started moving really fast towards Q and Chorongo. I was able to see her collar with the tape and ID tag very neatly, but I didnÕt see her again all day because she was very skittish and moving very fast. She got together again with her group when she arrived to Q and Chorongo at 8:42, which is when we saw Morpho and other sakis. They moved a bit and rested in a tall tree. 	This morning I went with Kelsey and Robyn to follow Lagothrix G and hopefully get some samples for hormone analysis. GaelÕs signal was coming from the Matapalo-Muercielago area. We were able to see Chai, Chalupe, Clash, Coco, Condrad, Chloe, Cuzco, Cora, Colugo, Celeste and Gwen. After feeding they started moving a bit north. We heard GaelÕs signal and it was really close. We found Gael about 50 meters ahead from where we were with group C. Gael was in Murcielago 150 eating Ficus from the LL-14-038. He was eating alone until a female with a juvenile male and followed by a subadult female arrived to the tree where Gael was feeding. When Gael started moving we started seeing more individuals that we presume were from group G. However, Clash and GwenÕs signal stayed close to where we were, towards the canopy walkway where the other fig tree LL-14-050 is. Gael and the rest of group G started moving towards the canopy walkway but didnÕt get to the tree. Kelsey and I were following group G and Robyn went to check on the LL-14-050 and all of group C was there, so group C and G were less than 100 meters away from each other! 
Robyn told me she was seeing spider monkeys feeding in the fig tree so I went to see if I could identify who they were and hopefully get a sample. The spider monkeys in the tree were a small adult female with a juvenile male and also a subadult male. The female had a dark patch on forehead and thin sideburns. She looked kind of small. At first I thought it was Vita and Vader, but the female didnÕt have a collar and she looked smaller that what I remember of Vita. The juvenile male was the size of Emilia or Loto (approx. 1.5 to 2 years old), and with a dark face. The subadult male had very thin sideburns, small testes and a medium sized patch on forehead, and his face was definitely different to Ayax or Summer who are the only two subadults (of similar size) in MQ-1. 
While the spiders were resting in the fig tree we started hearing really strong and non-friendly vocalizations. I could see some individuals from group C that were feeding in the fig tree leaving very fast and then I heard more vocalizations. I had the recording equipment that day so I was able to record some of the vocalizations. After this intergroup encounter happened some of the individuals from group C came back to the fig tree and group G started moving back to Matapalo. It was really interesting that the spiders and woollies were foraging at the same time in the tree, but then the woollies left for a bit and the spiders started resting in the tree. But as soon as some of the woollies came back the spiders left the tree and started moving somewhere else. We kept following group G along Matapalo and then they started moving towards camp along the Comedor trail. At this point Tony had arrived and we were trying to follow Goodwin who was a target monkey to get collared, as well as any adult female not carrying an infant/juvenile. When we were in the Comedor trail, monkeys started feeding leaves in the same tree where Tony darted Gwen. Tony tried darting a female but he missed. Then a female with a JM2 was feeding in the same tree and Tony tried darting her. We all thought he got her, but she never went groggy at all. They kept moving towards camp and rested a bit in Numa 25 (where Tony and Kelsey went to grab a coffee from the comedor), and then they kept moving south-east, along Numa and then Chichico. Today we tried again to look for Kauo to collect a fecal sample of Koinka. We left at 7:00 and walked along Guacamayo to Puma. At 7:56, around Puma ~300, we found Andreo eating in AB-07-011, an Iryanthera. We decided to continue searching for Kauo, so we left Andreo behind. We walked up the rest of Puma and then to the Attalea tree (AB-07-003) to try our luck there. Unfortunately, we did not have any luck there, nor did we have luck anywhere else in Puma Plot where we searched through Lines 6-3 between 200 and 800. Finally, because there was a lot of wind and the light was bad, we decided to go back to the station at around 12:00."OS96044		Taylor Rubin	3/11/13	1/0/00								GPS PP8	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"11, March, 2013 (OS98848, OS96044, OS98861), SA, TR, AL
We left for the field at 8:00 and found Nipa/Nina/Nika/Ana/Ayax/Sofia/Summer/Poto at 9:41 near the Attalea tree AB-07-003 where they have been feeding these last days. We saw Poto being groomed by Ana, but soon after he fissioned from the subgroup at 9:58. The group was mostly resting until Sofia and Summer fissioned from the group at 11:39. While resting Summer and Ayax played for a very long time while all other were resting. Then Nipa and Ana started foraging in AB-13-077 (Bombacaceae Matisia Cordata). They slowly moved SSE and ate from AB-13-078 (Moraceae Batocarpus Ramas Rojas) for quite some time. During all the day Ayax was quite far from the rest and vocalized alarm calls after hearing some antbird at least twice. He is behaving as an adult someties but still as a juvenile at other times. They alternated between resting in the tree and then foraging. At around 14:00, the monkeys heard a bird alarm calling and all of them began to do a repeating bark. By 14:14, all of the monkeys except for Ayax had stopped barking, but he continued to do so until 14:32, when Nika and then Nipa whinnied, after which he immediately stopped. 
After they finally started to move away from the Moraceae, an interesting thing happened. Nipa had crossed between two branches and then realized that Nina needed help to cross. She was too far from the other branch to make a bridge by herself, so she started squeaking and Ana leaned over to grab her hand from the adjacent tree so that Nipa and Ana made a bridge together and Nina crossed. At this point, they ate in AB-08-082 (Bombacacae Matisia Cordata). There was a very quick bout in which Nipa ate in a Virola AB-08-164 (Myristicaceae Virola), but that only lasted for a few minutes.
At 16:28 there was a quick fusion and then fission (at 16:33) with a juvenile female (maybe Lela?) who was making many lost calls. The group moved on, however, and started eating in  AB-13-079 (Arecaceae Oenocarpus). First, Nipa and Nina were eating in the Oenocarpus, but then Ana came and displaced Nipa. Nipa rested close by while Ana ate and then when Ana left, she re-entered the tree for another bout. At 16:55, right after leaving the tree, Ana and Ayax fissioned. 
At around 17:05, Nipa, Nika, and Nina entered the sleeping tree AB-06-089 at Puma 350. They foraged quickly on some new leaves (Moraceae Brosimum Lactesins) and then started to rest. AndrŽs left the field at 17:15 to talk to the veterinarian who had just arrived, and I stayed with the monkeys in the sleeping tree. They rested and Nina alternated between nursing from Nipa and playing with Nika. They were all in PC or P1 until 17:47 when there was a fusion with Eva/Eli/Emilia. They spread out more in the sleeping tree and then continued to rest while Eli (??) played by herself. I left the field at 17:56.
At 17:20 Ana and Ayax were sleeping in sleeping tree AB-08-145, immediately after they fissioned with Nipa. They went to sleep in different trees!"OS96045		Taylor Rubin	3/12/13	1/0/00								GPS PP8	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"12, March, 2013 (OS96045, OS98862), TR, AL
We left camp today at 5:30 with Victoria, the veterinarian, with the goal of finding Nipa in the sleeping tree where we left her last night. We arrived at the tree at 6:00, but there wasnÕt anyone in the tree. We decided to walk to the sleeping tree where AndrŽs found Ana and Ayax the night before, and luckily we found Eva, Emilia, Eli, Ana, and Ayax moving around Puma 0. We think Nipa and Eva micht not havesateys in AB-06-089 and maybe before sunset went to the other sleeping tree or else woke up very early and moved towards where Ana was sleepinig in AB-08-145. I started with a focal of Eva at 7:00 who was with Ana and Ayax. At 7:23, Sammy fusioned with the group right around the Batocarpus from which they were eating yesterday (AB-13-078). Soon thereafter, at 7:28, there was another fusion with Andreo and Mono, at 7:42, with Vita, Violeta, Vader, Nipa, Nika, Nina, Sofia, and Summer, and at 7:49 with Lucas. It seemed as if they were gtting together to go to the lick in the ridge near G-825. I switched focals to Vita when she came into the group. Luna, Lela, and Loto probably came with Nipa, Vita, and Sofia, as well, but we did not see them until 8:36, so we canÕt be sure. Everyone was resting and foraging in and around the Batocarpus and several juveniles were playing, notably Vader and  Loto. 
At around 9:00, everyone started moving away from the area, but in different directions. We found ourselves with Andreo, Sammy, Mono, Lucas, Luna, Lela, Loto, Sofia, and Summer heading WNW through the area between Guacamayo and Puma. I switched focals to Sammy at this point, but he was moving very, very quickly out of view until 10:20 when we caught up with him at Guacamayo 1700 about 100 meters before you hit the moretal. At this point, the subgroup consisted of Andreo, Sammy, and Lucas. At 10:30, there was a fusion with Nenki and then at 10:54, there was another fusion with Poto. Both Poto nd Nenki were in the west and the other three males went running very fast towards the west (from the east) and they all met there. The males moved WSW and began to rest right on the edge of the lagoon. Sammy and Lucas were playing for a long time, wrestling.
We rested for a long time with the males there. At around 13:00, all of the males started a long bout of repeating barks and they were fixating on something on the ground. We did not see anything, however. The repeating barks went on for about an hour, with individuals coming in and out of the vocalization sequence. 
The males started moving again at around 15:00, and Lucas and Sammy were foraging in Iriartea, eating both the fruits and the spikes (or trying to eat the spikes, in LucasÕ case). I switched focals to Lucas. By 15:30, the males were all moving in different directions from Maquisapa 4350, but we stayed with Lucas who was resting just above the trail. ItÕs possible that Lucas fissioned from the others at this point, but we left him then, so itÕs also possible that he met up with one or more of the other individuals soon thereafter. 
We left the field at 15:30 because Victoria had a very bad headache."OS96048		Taylor Rubin	3/15/13	1/0/00							I am using PP6 today and Palm 07; Palm 10 stopped working properly so March 13 and 14 data is on Andres' Palm (07)	GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"15, March, 2013 (OS96048, OS98865), TR, AL
Today AndrŽs and I left camp at 6:50 to see if we could find a male in MQ-1 to dart. At 7:32, we found Eva, Eli, and Emilia moving between trees around Guacamayo 250m and we decided to follow them. They ran very quickly directly towards AB-13-069Ña Virola that we marked the last time we were following these individuals. They proceeded to eat in the Virola for 50 minutes without resting. Finally, at 8:35, Eva started to rest with Emilia on her back (though Eli continued to eat). It was raining pretty steadily and the sky was very grey, so AndrŽs and I decided to go back to camp and wait until it cleared up a little to find a male. We were at camp from around 10:00 to 11:30 and then we went out again as it had gotten a little bit brighter (though not much). We decided to do phenology while looking for monkeys so that we could take advantage if we saw them, but also be productive if we didnÕt. We didnÕt end up seeing any monkeys, but we did finish the phenology for the trails (Guacamayo, Puma, Maquisapa, and Harpia)."OS96049		Taylor Rubin	3/16/13	1/0/00								GPS PP8	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"16, March, 2013 (OS96049, OS98866), TR, AL
We left camp at 6:15 with Gary (who is studying the pygmies) and Veronica (the veterinarian) in search of MQ-1 males to try to dart. At 6:59, we heard a repeating bark from Guacamayo 825, 200m, 330 degrees. There were multiple monkeys barking. They came towards us after the barking stopped and started eating Batocarpus (Ramas Rojas; AB-13-078). The group composition at this point was Luna/Lela/Loto/Eva/Eli/Emilia. At 7:34, Luna stopped eating to rest and she briefly nursed Loto. 
There was a fission at 7:45 when Eva, Eli, and Emilia left moving quickly ESE. We think she might have gone straight to the Virola where we were with her yesterday (AB-13-069). We stayed with Luna, however, and she rested for a long time with Loto playing by herself within one meter of Luna. We are not sure where Lela was, but probably resting out of view in the same tree. 
At 8:36 there was a fusion with Lucas. He didnÕt seem to eat any batocarpus when he arrived; just rested somewhere in the tree out of view. At 9:58, there was a fission and we decided to stay with Lucas to see if we could dart him. He left by himself heading west and stopped a couple times; once to eat Iriartea and once to eat Naucleopsis Ulei in AB-07-136. He rested around the Naucleopsis tree for a while, but then started moving very quickly south west and we lost him between Guacamayo and Lago at 11:56. Unfortunately, we did not find any other monkeys and returned to camp at 14:30 because it was very grey and starting to rain."OS96050		Taylor Rubin	3/17/13	1/0/00								GPS PP8	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"17, March, 2013 (OS96050, OS98867), TR, AL
Today AndrŽs finished up the phenology in Harp’a Plot and then Veronica and I met him at Harpia 1,700 so that we could go to the salt lick and change the position of the camera trap. We stayed there until 13:30 because we heard monkeys around. There were definitely chorongos, but at some point we are pretty sure that there were spider monkeys around, as well. In any case, they never appeared, so we decided to look for an MQ-1 male to dart. We walked down Matamata to Chorongo, and ended up finding Evita and Elena resting about 20m north of Chorongo 800m. AndrŽs left at 15:30 to enter the phenology data and Veronica and I stayed with the monkeys. After resting, they foraged around the area and ate Oenocarpus (AB-10-043).
At 16:07, they fused with Eva, Eli, and Emilia and they all ate IngaÑthe larga amarilla, and then a small round fruit in bunches from a tree with small leaves on opposite sides of a stem. I didnÕt know the name of the fruit and could not find a sample, but I marked the tree as AB-13-081. At 17:00, they fissioned again and we were left with just Evita and Elena. They entered AB-07-156, a sleeping tree, at 17:05 and stayed there resting until we left them at 17:50.
AndrŽs wanted me to note that the females seem to be very solitary as of late."OS96051		Taylor Rubin	3/18/13	1/0/00								GPS PP8	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"18, March, 2013 (OS96051, OS98868), TR, AL

AndrŽs fired a dart at Sammy, but it missed by a tiny bit and stuck into the branch right below where Sammy had been sitting. Although Sammy ran away, the group as a whole did not flee and there wasnÕt any sense of group-wide panic. Next, AndrŽs fired a dart at Olio, but it was also unsuccessful and he missed by just a few centimeters. Luckily, this time we were able to recover the dart.

I saw Nenki and Olio and Kauoka, at least, in the trees high above the cave, but they did not go down and they did stay in the same place for long. Buka entered the lick at 11:56. Although I tried my best to enter the data on entrances and exits correctly, it was a real struggle for me. I noted it in my palm, but I would not use my data from today as I do not at all feel confident about it. Nonetheless, I can make some general comments. We found Luna, Liana and Lela at the sleeping tree in Puma 200 at 6:10 and they did not move out of the tree until almost 10:00. It was a very ÒlazyÓ day as they moved only a couple hundred meters away from the tree and came back. The fed from some Paullinia, Spondias, Perebea, Iriartea and some leaves. They would rest for a long periodn then move to the next feeding tree, eat a little and then rest again. Lela sometimes travels by herself close to Luna. Luna groomed Liana several times. At 16:00 they came back to the sleeping tree and went to sleep (most probably) as we left them at 16:05 in the tree. I think this pattern of little activity resembles the behavior last year with Nelson when there were few fruits in the forest; also the bad weather might infulence these ranging patterns."OS98306		Sara Alvarez	7/18/10	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"July 18, 2010 (0S98306, AV98316 )SA, RT, AL
We found the spider monkey group (MQ-1) near Guacamayo 350 at 11:03 after AL made two VLC and several spiders responded. They seemed to be quite spread out as some monkeys called from near the camp area, whilst others called from Guacamayo or even the Puma area. We found Nenki while feeding in Spondias and soon after Sammy got there after a long bout of VLC from several group members. At 11:38 Lucas joined the subgroup and there were some other individuals relatively near (within vocal range). The 3 males moved towards the north and at 11:47 another subgroup joined. The subgroup included the 3 males (Sm, Lc and Nk) and several other that came by including (Pt, Mn, Ad, An, Ai, Ay, Ln,Li, Le). They started miving north very fast and the two females were left behind and only the six males headed north. They begun a boundary patrol and all males would be moving in straight line very fast, but relatively silently through the upper canopy.The reached Harpia 900 and went into an emergent tree and were all resting and being RVS. After several minutes they begun moving north, still in straight line and then moved into the area within Matamata and Harpia, were no other group of spider monkeys usually ranges, but that may define the border between MQ-1, MQ-2 and MQ-3. At some point two of the males were feeding in an Attalea tree and a Capuchin came trying to feed but was ÒthreatenedÓ by VSQ and did not come into the tree. In the afternoon they reached an area were they remained for the rest of the day, and fed from several Oenocarpus trees to finally go into a large sleeping tree AB-10-071 at 17:00. Sammy, Lucas and Nenki stayed in the tree in contact, just resting near each other, and it seemed that the 6 males remained in the area. There was an evident patrol towards the east of the range."OS98307		Sara Alvarez	7/19/10	1/0/00							".........alL these males were here yesterday, may be they are here too"	GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"19 July 2010 (OS98307, AV98319) RT, SA, AL
We found the six males from MQ-1 in the sleeping tree in between Matamata and Harpia (AB-10-071) and during the day (until 13:00) they remained in the same area, very vigilant and frequently going into large emergent trees to rest and be vigilant. All six males remained in the area the whole time and they rested in proximity and contact at most times. I transcribed the data, dump the data and correct the mistakes while the students draw the pictures of the monkeys and the map."OS98391		Sara Alvarez	11/10/10	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"10-November-2010 (OS98391) SA, AG, LS
In the morning we went to check the sleeping tree in Puma, AB-10-064, and we found them around the tree.  We identified Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Luna, Liana, Lela, Violet and Vita.  We started a focal with Vita because it was easy for the students to identify her by the collar.  We tried to identify the juveniles so they could practice identifying them.  As I did the focal on Vita, the students practiced describing what she was doing, using the ethogram codes.  Like the previous days they were traveling in a big subgroup so it was difficult to identify them and follow a focal.  We followed them down Guacamayo and then they went to the Moretal.  Before they went to the Moretal, they fissioned and we changed the focal to Luna who was RFV for a long time.  When she arrived in the Moretal with Liana and Lela they ate red fruit in several trees (Perebea) and then spent more than four hours eating termites in a palm tree.  They fusioned in that tree with Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Eva, Ergie, Eli at 12:00 and with Poto and Evita at 13: 10 and with Buka and Boa at 13:50 and with Kauo and Kauoka at 16:15.  We are pretty sure they were eating termites because we could distinguish termite housing in a piece of fallen bark.  We could tell they were eating something, but it was too small to determine.  We marked the tree as AB-10-151.  While they ate, they were very close to eachother.  Several times we saw Poto push the females and juveniles in the tree.  We followed them to another tree where they continued to forage.  At around 18:00 they were still foraging red fruit in the same tree so we marked the tree in our GPS to return the next day.  We could hear vocalizing in nearby trees and assumed they were going to sleep in this area."OS98392		Sara Alvarez	11/11/10	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"11-November-2010 (OS98392) SA, AG, LS
In the morning we took a boat to Lago trail since the monkeys spent the night near the Moretal.  We waited until 7:35 at the same tree that we left the monkeys in the night before.  At 7:35 Evita and Elena appeared so we decided to follow them.  We heard some VLCÕs before spotting Evita and Elena, so we think Evita might have made the call.  She was eating red fruits in the tree for less than five minutes and then she went to the palm AB-10-151.  She was eating termites for a long time but we noticed that the infant was very inactive.  We were concerned the infant was malnourished, although it was very hard to tell.  She was moving and FV for over an hour.  We heard some VLCÕs so we came back to the palm and while we were waiting there Sofia, Silvi and Summer appeared at 10:40.  They were eating the termites for a long time.  At one point we saw Summer trying to get on SofiaÕs back, but Sofia pushed him off because she was eating.  They began MBT and fusioned at 13:54 with Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Luna, Liana, Lela, Eva, Ergie and Eli.  At 14:40 we could not find Sofia, so we changed our focal to Luna who was eating spikes in a palm.  She was vocalizing a strange sound, but similar to a VRB and it appeared that she was waiting for the infant.  They moved to a nearby tree where they ate red fruits for a long time. I could not mark the tree because I did not have any more tacks.  Around 16:00 Luna fissioned with Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Eva, Ergie and Eli.  She continued to FFV.  We left them in that tree at 17:30 because she was RFV."OS98393		Sara Alvarez	11/12/10	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"12-November-2010 (OS98393) SA, AG, LS

They were eating fruits (small Virola) in a tree which I marked as AB-11-112. They fusioned with Nenki in that area at 8:39 and they went to T 200. They fusioned with Lucas and Sammy and they moved together towards Chorongo. The males were near Vita and Vita and Violeta were playing for a while with Sammy and Lucas too who were very close each other with Nenki. Then they left the tree and I though that Vita was with them but I think she was RFV in that tree. They fissioned with her at 10:00 and they moved fast towards the sal lick. Nenki and Lucas were VCK very close toching and looked me like a display. 
SALT LICK
They arrived to the salt lick at 10:25 and they fusioned with  Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Buka, Boa, Luna, Liana, Lela, Mika, Mali, Maquis, Oikamo, Olio and Andreo. We saw Mika doing lots of displays towards the ground, but not high up in the canopy.

At around 13:00 they left the area and at 13:30 they fissioned and the subgroup was Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita, Elena, Luna, Liana, Lela, Oikamo, Olio, Andreo, Lucas, Sammy and Nenki. Today we went through Guacamayo and Puma trail and found the monkeys in Puma 150. It was a sunny day from the beginning and we thought they were going to visit the salt lick in GP, given that we heard them vocalizing (VRBs) since before 6:27am. We found Ana, Eva and Evita who were the ones doing the VRBs. Then we saw some others coming from the east part, and around 7am there was a fusion with Andreo, Oikamo, Nipa, Vita, Nenki and Lucas. Lots of vocalizations were heard from the east and southwest of GP. They started to move away from the salt lick area, moving rapidly towards east and then they went into the Puma plot and started to move a lot through Line 0, and then moved a little bit NW.  They all continued moving, and around line 3-200, at 9:00, there was a fusion with Luna, Liana and Lela. Then they moved a little bit more to NW and they ate a while of Lauraceae and then rested in that tree for about one hour. 

There were a lot of SOCIAL INTERACTIONS while they were resting:
-	Nenki was playing a lot with the juveniles, specifically with Ayax, Ergie and Aisha.
-	Ayax and Aisha played over Lucas.
-	Sammy and Lucas were resting in contact for a short while.
-	Sammy, Lucas and Nenki were resting very close to each other, about 3 or 4 meters between them.
-	The juveniles kept playing over the adult males, and they moved to another site to rest. We could notice then that Nenki was in contact with Lela while resting. Lela seemed to be solo playing while Nenki was resting, and apparently she started to ÒplayÓ by touching NenkiÕs testicles. It looked like it was some sort of MASTURBATION since he started to have an erection and I saw some liquid (looked like sperm) coming out of his penis. While he had the erection, Lela continued ÒplayingÓ, touching NenkiÕs testicles and penis, pulling it several times, and Nenki just kept resting. At some point, Liana joined Lela, and she was also pulling NenkiÕs penis, like if they were playing. Apparently they were pulling too hard, and Nenki changed its position, and then he started to play with Liana and Lela.
-	Nenki played with Lela and Liana.
-	Nenki rested in proximity of 1 meter with Luna.
While they were resting, or before (before 9:30), there was a fusion with Sammy, Mono and Poto; and Nipa apparently left the subgroup. Therefore, we stayed with Luna, Eva, Evita, Ana, Oikamo, and all the males. They started to move more the northwest very quickly without stopping. They crossed Maquisapa trail around 12:30, and at some point we didnÕt see Ana anymore. They continued moving very fast, northwest of Maquisapa trail, moving outside of the trail system. We followed them since we thought that it couldÕve been a BOUNDARY PATROL with MQ-3Õs territory. Therefore, we were expecting that at some point the males fissioned and left the females behind, but instead, they all kept moving very close to each other, and even sometimes the females were leading the way. Males were moving very close to each other, at a distance of about 5 to 10 meters between them. They kept moving North, and were travelling very low in the canopy, without being aware of us. They werenÕt vocalizing much, and no other VLCs were heard after they started moving far north. 
NEW SALT LICK:
When we were about 1km far north from Maquisapa trail, around 13:50, the monkeys stopped and we saw them resting. They were resting vigilant, looking a lot to the ground, and we also saw Lucas doing displays to us twice. They started to move very low, like going to the ground. We saw them moving almost in the ground, and going up very fast, like when they are in the salt lick. About 15 minutes after we saw that, we saw Eva and Ergie coming up the trees with their faces completely covered with mud, so we could confirm that they were in a NEW SALT LICK! We saw all of them going up with their faces and feet covered with mud. They were there for about an hour. While we were waiting, and seeing them go to the ground, we heard one VLC very far (more or less 400mts) coming from North (probably MQ-6), but we didnÕt see the monkeys from MQ-1 very aware of it, they just kept going down. 

They left the salt lick at 15:34, and started to go back through the same route they used to get there. Nonetheless, they moved much slower, rested and ate fruits in their way, and were also vocalizing much more, including VWHs and loud VLCs (as if they didnÕt were in another groupÕs territory). This is why then we though it probably wasnÕt a boundary patrol, but instead their target was mainly the salt lick. They arrived back to Maquisapa trail, MS 2100, around 17:45, and we left them there since we were very far away from camp."OS98449		Sara Alvarez	3/12/11	1/0/00								GPS PP5	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"12-March-2011 (OS98449) SA, LA

It was still rainig so it was difficult to follow them but I could see very well my focal Sofia, all the time. They were eating in AB-11-118 and at around 12:00 Sammy fissioned with the subgroup (I do not know exactly at what time because it was raining). They spent around 4 hours and a half in that tree (between 11:00 and 15:30). Sofia was RPA more than one hour while it was raining with Summer near RFV and the rest of the sugroup resting too. At 13:14 they fusioned with Mika, Mali and Maquis and at around 13:30 stopped raining and they were eating in AB-11-118 around two hours (almost all the time). At 15:30 they moved towards the moretal where they started to eat wood in a tree that I marked as AB-11-119 and in AB-10-151, but mainly in the first one. They were very close to each other eating. It seemed that they drink water too because they were inside the tronk and I could see water too. At 16:14 I saw an aggression between Mika and Buka with Silvi, I think Buka and Mika aggressed Silvi while they are eating wood. They were around one hour eating in that tronk and I saw Sofia aggressed Summer because he wanted to go up to the top of her back and she refused. Then they were near the moretal and west and they were eating Inga in AB-08-029. At around 18:00 they went to the sleeping tree that I marked as AB-11-120 (Sofia and Buka, and the rest of the subgroup slept around the sleeping tree). It was a palm and I left the monkeys sleeping at 18:10."OS98464		Sara Alvarez	3/27/11	1/0/00								GPS PP5	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"27-March-2011 (OS98464) SA

We went through Guacamayo and in Guacamayo 1300 we heard NenkiÕs signal coming from south. We moved south to see if we could get closer, but about 60-80mts south of Guacamayo, it was already flooded. At that point we started hearing lots of VLCs (7:26am), very close to us, and also responding far away from south, like from Lago trail, and they kept calling a lot until 8:28am. At 8:28 we saw Sammy jumping out from a tree near to us, and started moving in the direction of the VLCs we heard coming from South. We went back and kept moving all the way through, up to the end of Guacamayo. Around Guacamayo 1875 we saw a spider monkey, but we couldnÕt identify it.

Luckily, he rested there and we were able to download the GPS data, and upload the new calendar.  Then we went back to where we had heard NenkiÕs signal, near the lagoon, and there we heard his signal coming from south. We went across the lagoon by boat, and about 60-80 meters away from the river (inside the forest Ð but extremely flooded Ð ), we saw a group of spider monkeys moving very close to the water level. We saw Lucas, Nenki (only signal, but very very close, without the antennae we had a strong signal), Sammy, Sofia, Silvi, Summer, Kauo, Kauoka, and maybe others, hanging around this flooded area. Resting day."OS98582		Sara Alvarez	4/7/12	1/0/00								GPS PP2	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"07, April, 2012 (OS98582), SA, LA, AP
Today Laura, Ana and I went to look for Nenki since last night we checked his signal and it was coming from Chorongo. We found Nenki, Andreo, Sammy, Poto and Mono resting between Chorongo and Matapalo at 7:13 (it rained earlier in the morning). After resting, they began to move towards the end of Chorongo. While moving, Andreo, Poto and Mono ate from an Attalea tree (AB-10-053) and while eating they all remained in P1. When they arrived to Chorongo (the end bit) some of them ate a while from the Virola AB-08-134 and some rested. Mono and Andreo rested in P1 for a short while. Sammy and Poto rested about 4 meters distance. While resting, Eva, Ergie and Eli joined the subgroup at 8:20 and Lucas, Evita and Elena arrived at 9:08. They rested for another while and then began to move towards the salt lick. While moving, some of them ate a while from Inga sp. and meanwhile some of the males rested. While resting, Poto and Sammy rested in P1 for about 8 minutes, and when Sammy left proximity, Lucas approached to Poto and they both remained resting in P1. Then they continued moving towards the salt lick. 

They arrived to the salt lick at 10:36 When they arrived to the salt lick area there was a fusion with Ana, Aisha, Ayax, Luna, Liana, Lela. They rested for a while and at 11:29 others arrived to the salt lick and there was a fusion with Buka, Boa, Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Sofia, Summer, Mika, Maquis, Vita, Violeta and Olio. When we saw Mika, we noticed that her belly is super big as if she is pregnant!!! Inside the salt lick, we saw Ayax and Nenki playing for a short while, until Ayax left and Nenki remained resting vigilant. Around 11:50 we saw that Sofia and Maquis began to move in the lower branches, and then we saw Ana, Lucas and Olio also moving very low. At 12:17 a small juvenile females (Boa or Elena) was the first one to go inside the salt lick, while Olio was still vigilant in the branch that leads to the salt lick. At 12:21 Olio went inside the lick (12:21, 12:36, 12:56), followed by Sofia (12:21), Lucas (12:21, 12:23, 12:28, 12:39), Eli (12:24), Poto (12:25), Ana (12:25), Buka (12:25), Julieta (12:28, 13:04), Kauo (12:28, without carrying Koinka), Liana (12:28), Sammy (12:31, 12:57, 13:12), Evita (12:31, 12:49, 13:19), Nenki (12:34, 13:19), Kauoka (12:35), Andreo (12:36, 12:50, 13:08), Ergie (12:37), Eva (12:40), Mono (12:42), Luna (12:57, 13:16), and Vita (13:09). After eating, they remained resting inside the salt lick area and while resting we saw howler monkeys inside too (at 13:30). When I first saw the howlers, was when two juveniles or subadults (one male one female) were licking NenkiÕs back which was full of mud stuck to his hair. They licked Nenki for about two minutes while Nenki rested, and then they began to move lower getting closer to the lick. At 14:15 we saw the howler monkeys going down to eat from the salt lick. At 14:27 we saw Mika again in the branch leading to the lick, while the howler monkeys were still going down to eat, and after less than a minute, Mika went inside the lick again. At 14:28 we saw a subadult howler monkey going inside the lick while Mika was still inside. After that, we saw Ana, Ayax, Ergie and Elena moving in lower branches again. At 14:38 the howlers began to leave the salt lick and at 14:49 we saw Kauo going inside the salt lick again (again, without Kauoka). She was followed by Sammy (14:51, 14:57, 15:01) and Olio (14:51, 15:06, 15:10), then Buka (14:52, 15:15), Sofia (14:56), Ergie (14:59), Julieta (15:02, 15:05, 15:06), Poto (15:03, 15:09 Ð after dropping his chunk to the ground Ð ), Eli (15:03), Luna (15:05), Liana (15:06), Ayax (15:10), Ergie (15:13), Andreo (15:14, 15:16), Lucas (15:18), Mika (15:19), and Sofia (15:19). At 15:25, we heard that they were leaving the salt lick. 

We went outside, and some were still around, but some began to move SE while others began to move towards Puma trail. There was a fission at ___ and we were left with Nenki, Andreo, Sammy, Poto, Lucas, Olio, Evita, Elena, Vita, Violeta, Eva, Ergie and Eli. For a moment, I couldnÕt see Sammy and Andreo (my focal animal) so I switched to Evita, but about an hour later I saw Sammy again in the Sapotaceae trees near R transect, so I switched back to Sammy. They began to move south, crossing Guacamayo trail and then going south until they arrived around R transect where they began to feed from several Sapotaceae trees around (AB-12-104, AB-12-097, AB-12-118). Nenki, Vita, Violeta, Eva, Ergie, Eli, Evita and Elena arrived first, and some began to vocalize VLCs a lot (some of them from Evita), and short after that, the rest of the males arrived. After feeding, they rested for a while. While resting, Andreo was in P1 with Nenki and Poto. After that they began to move a bit north. They fissioned and I followed Andreo, Nenki, Poto, Olio and Lucas at 17:45 . Vita, Violeta, Eva, Ergie and Eli remained in a tree near R 125 and the rest kept moving north. Evita mustÕve stayed around. Sammy was moving along with the rest of the group but while the rest kept moving, he stayed behind and began to move towards Lago trail (Ana and Laura followed them). I kept following the rest of the group towards west. They were MBT very fast and I left them at 18:10 when they crossed Danta (they still MBT towards west). Sammy and Eva slept near R70."OS98583		Sara Alvarez	4/8/12	1/0/00								GPS PP2	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"08, April, 2012 (OS98583), SA, LA, AP
Today I went to look for Nenki with the telemetry and I heard some VLC near R. When I arrived to the Sapotaceae«s tree I followed Sammy, Eva, Evita and Vita and Ana and Laura were following them, so I decided to look for someone else because we heard some VLCs towards Lago. I found Andreo, Poto and Lucas in Lago near Songo Songo and they started to move towards north and east. Sara coming with Lucas, Andreo, Poto, (7:37) and Nenki and Olio also arrived short after (fusion at 7:44). They ate for a while and then began moving NW like moving towards the salt lick. They passed through the salt lick and kept moving towards Puma trail and further NW (while moving, Sammy was leading the subgroup several times) until they encountered Kauo, Kauoka, Koinka, Buka, Boa, Mika, Maquis, Sofia, Summer, Ana, Aisha, Ayax and Julieta (fusion at 8:48). For a moment, Laura saw Olio, Kauoka and Nenki playing for a short while, until we started to hear VGRs and saw there was an aggression where Lucas was chasing Ergie down a tree trunk and he lunged towards her trying to bite her, but apparently he missed; but right after Ergie looked her foot as if she was trying to see if it was hurt or not. At the same time, we saw Sofia, Eva and Mika very low near the ground and looking vigilantly above of them, and meanwhile they were vocalizing a lot of VGR. Some other juveniles and subadults were around the aggression and looking vigilantly down. Right after the aggression, we observed Ana and Mika embracing and VWH. After the aggression, Ayax remained in contact with Eva, and it seemed like Ayax was scared. When things calmed down, they rested there for a while, and meanwhile the juveniles played. While resting, Laura saw Sammy and Poto in P1 for a short while. When they began to move, they ate a short while from a cf. Menispermaceae tree (AB-12-105) and around 10:30 they began to move back east like moving towards the salt lick area. They were moving most of the time  crossing Chorongo and Q towards Harpia. At 12:25 it started rainig and I though I had lost them but I found them again at 13:05 near Chorongo 200 and I followed them towards Harpia. In that moment a conga stung me and I could not see very well what had happened. They were RFV for a while and started to move towards north near Harpia again. At around 14:30 started to rain hard and I coudnt follow because the pain on my hand, because the conga, so I decided to go back to the lab and work in the lab."OS98584		Sara Alvarez	4/9/12	1/0/00								GPS PP2	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"09, April, 2012 (OS98584), SA, LA, AP

Today Laura and I went to look for MQ-2. We went to Harpia trail 1450 where there is an Iryanthera tree (AB-12-068) and we waited there for a while. We arrived there around 9am and around 9:30 we heard someone defecating in the Iryanthera tree. We saw several spider monkeys that were resting. We saw:

DEMOGRAPHY: 
-	AF (probably WENTAMO): Very dark face, totally black and prominent anus, black dot at the tip of clitoris. 
-	JM (WentamoÕs son): Dark face, a bit of pink on the outer sides of the eyes, hair around mouth is grayish; no dots on anus, a bit prominent. Size between Ayax and Olio. 
-	AF(#2): Large and light coloured forehead patch with an oval-shape in the middle, but also extended sideways. Clitoris and anus without any dots, very pink, prominent anus (similar to EvitaÕs); small body; whitish hair around mouth (similar to Poto); this but well definied sideburns; no pink around eyes.
-	JM (AF#2Õs son): dark face, but very pink nose and mouth (similar to Nika); dark forehead but with a small circled patch at the tip of the mohawk; very thin but defined sideburns; prominent anus without dots. Size similar to Ayax. 
-	JF?: We saw a big juvenile (or small subadult female), with a very bright face, pinkish nose and mouth, with a patch thin half-moon shaped and placed in the very top part of the forehead; and with a black anus with a pink dot at the very tip of the anus.

Last night Ana left several monkeys sleeping near R 175 so today we went there to look for them. We found them at 5:48am when someone pooped. While Andreo was resting, Laura saw him in contact with Ergie and Violeta, and they both groomed Andreo for a while. At a moment, Ergie moved closer to Andreo, and he bit her arm but softly, and then they sort of began to play but for less than a minute, and then Ergie groomed Andreo for another while. Around 10am it began to rain very heavily and they all went up into the middle of the tree which was with lots of vines and lianas. Eva was resting most of the time and in P1 with Lucas for a while in AB-12-097. While it was raining very hard, lots of the juveniles (Eli, Ergie, Lela, Violeta and Olio) were playing like crazy, moving between trees chasing each other and for a long while. Lucas groomed his right foot for a while, he might have a wound because I saw him yesterday doing the same, and Olio groomed LucasÔ foot a couple of times too. They kept moving until they got to Harpia 475, they got there and started raining. They rested for a while, until the rain stopped and then they started to move west (7:30). They rested in a big tree. Here Lucas was in P2 with Nenki and in P1 and PC with Olio. Olio and Lucas played for a short while, Olio was wrapping his tail around LucasÔ arm and Lucas played back for a few seconds after moving away to rest some more. -	AF: Wentamo
-	JM: her son. His face is very dark with a pink nose. His anus was prominent. Size between Ayax and Olio. 
-	SF: she had a half moon yellow spot in her forehead with a faded line in the middle, similar than Poto«s mark. She has noticeable sideburns and grey around her eyes. His nose was pig-grey (despigmentado) like Julieta«s colour but darker. Her anus was black. Size a little bit bigger than Julieta.
-	AF2: She has an orange half moon with a slight peak on the bottom part (similar than Oikamo but thicker). Her sideburns were faded but thick and like messy at the end near the eyes. After this they started moving north, ate more Oenocarpus and close to line 9-400 ate some UNK fruits (AB-12-201). When we were there the sky was really dark... it was windy and the clouds were dark gray.. At 17:05 when they were still feeding it started raining. Since we were far we left the monkeys and decided to go back to camp... when we were on Line 9-300 it stopped raining.. so we went back to the feeding tree and found no one! Today we went to download the WentamoÕs Gps collar data but when we were in Harpia 700 we realized that we didnÕt have the frequency of her collar. We went to the camp and we looked for the capture report in the dell computer but we couldnÕt find it. So we came back to the field trying with some codes that it sounded familiar to Nabilah and Leo but it werenÕt these numbers. Luckily, we found Wentamo on the way (Harpia 10-550). We download the data without any problem and we checked the frequency which was 150.580. We checked the battery and the real capacity was 80% and the expected capacity was 86%. Then we checked the signal with the antenna and we had some problems. First we checked the receiver without the antenna (only with the cable) and it didnÕt work, we didnÕt heard anything and Wentamo was right there. Then we checked with the antenna and the signal was too low, only when we put the gain very high we could hear the signal but not with a low gain (she was very near and we usually use low gain and without antenna and we usually hear the signal very well in that distance. The problem wasnÕt the cable because we tried with 2 and one was new, maybe the receiver? Otherwise we download the data correctly. Then we followed her for a while. She was with Wipo and with another AF, JM and AM that we couldnÕt identify because they moved fast and we couldnÕt see them very well. They were eating in a Sapotaceae tree AB-12-265 near line 8-500. I wait there but at 8:00 started to rain hard so I came back to the camp. I was organized my data and finished some things until stop raining. 
In the afternoon when it stopped raining, I went to look for Wentamo. I heard the signal pretty soon and very well (with some interferences, but much better than yesterday), I guess because I was within the plot closer to camp and not in the north of the plot. Anyway, I followed Wentamo who was with an adult male, I couldnÕt see his face but the anus looked like Sammy«s anus but I couldnÕt identify him. When they were very close to me and resting I turn on the lenovo but it was very slow and when it finished, the monkeys were movingÉ so I hadnÕt enough time to download the data... so I followed them with the signal again and suddenly I heard a lot of vocalizations. 
INTER-GROUP ENCOUNTER!!!
I was in line 4-0 and at 15:18 I saw a female, subadult I think, with dark face and yellowish half moon in her forehead who was VLC repeatly. Other monkeys were VLC around 50 meters from her (responding the females VLC) and I saw a male who was very close to her, around two meters away. I realized that this male was Andreo!, who did a display towards me, and then I saw Nenki (so there was no doubts they were MQ-1, IT WAS AN INTER-GROUP ENCOUNTER!!!!). Nenki approached to them and just when he arrived (15:22), Andreo and Nenki started to AGGRESS her (and I still having the Wentamos«s signal). When they was aggressing the female some MQ2 males approached and Nenki and Andreo left the female behind (who defecated but I took the sample and it was only seed) and went towards them (it seemed that they used the female to attract MQ2 males, I think). They started to AGRESS EACH OTHER, I saw Lucas too (and probably Sammy and Mono but I am not sure) and MQ-1 males were following MQ2 males which moved very fastÉ It was crazy, a lot of monkeys moving everywhere very fast vocalizing all the time, but VLC, I think calling for help. I couldnÕt see too much because they were moving fast but I was under them at the time when the big fight happened. They were moving low and moving in circles, following and showing their teeth (but I couldnÕt see physical aggressions, but it is probable). At 15:35 they split out but not very far each other, they were calm for some minutes and at 15:42 started to VLC again until 15:45. At 15:47 started to VLC again, mainly the SF, and at 15:48 a strong VLC, and they started to approach again.  Then some monkeys left the subgroup and I focus on 3, one MQ-2 male, the female and Nenki who were around 30 meters away. At 15:53, the MQ2 male, who have a yellow half-moon in his forehead and small pink anus, approached to the female, who was still vocalizing all the time. The SF was very dark with a half-moon not very clear. She had pink anus a little bit ÒsalidoÓ and pink clitorix without any spot. It seemed that he checked she was ok, and then she left proximity, but 15:55 Nenki was around 25 meter away vigilant, MWI. At 15:57 all of them were calm, resting and vigilant. The female started to move a little bit leaving Nenki and the other male behind but not very far. At 16:24 the female started to move again, slowly and at 16:26 we are in the line 5-100 and she was RFV with the rest around but it is very windy the monkeys moved streamly slow, without noise and fast, so I couldnÕt see where they moved but I could follow the female who moved only a little and I left her near line 5-50 with MQ-1, at least I could see Nenki, around. The rest of the individuals maybe were around because I couldnÕt see movement, but I donÕt know if they left... I didnt have the Wentamo«s signal neither. Tomorrow we will check the area trying to know who slept around.

In the morning I was working in the lab, checking my data, correcting my mistakes to pass my data to Access and Excell. When I was about to pass my data I realized that there were two copies of the database so I wanted to be sure which one was the last version so I didnÕt pass my data until ask about it Amy and Nabilah who was working with the database the day before.

So I went through Harpia, transect T and line -50 and I heard the signal finally in line 10. I tried the signal without the antenna and it wasnÕt very clear although I was certain she was right there because I could see her, and sometimes didnÕt work. But when I moved the cable or touched the contact I could hear the signal. They were moving but it started to rain and Wentamo and Wipo were resting in a tree in PC for a while and Goma and Gobi were eating fruits in the Cecropia tree for a couple of minutes and then resting too. Then they moved a little while it was still raining and Wentamo and Wipo were eating in a Oenocarpus tree AB-12-209 (which fruits seemed old). Then all of them were eating in a Cecropia tree, Gobia and Wipo moving close to each other and close to Wentamo most of the time. They went towards South and at 16:30 they arrived to line 10. I left the monkeys there because I canÕt see very well because of the rain but I could check several times the signal of the collar and it is working properly. I came back to the camp and I arrived at 17:30 and I transcribed the focal because I had made changes in handbase which I didnÕt have in my palm, and it was easier to pass only the focal there, and I dumped my data to Access and Excell (the data was already ready to pass because I had checked it in the morning)."OS98746		Sara Alvarez	11/6/12	1/0/00								None	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"6, November, 2012 (OS98746), SA

Protium tree AB-07-094. They moved towards Chorongo, near Ch 1225 and they were eating in the Virola tree AB-08-134. Then they were eating in a Pouruma tree (peluda) AB-13-013 and AB-13-014.  They moved towards West again and they were eating in another Virola AB-12-008. Then they rest for some minutes and they fusioned with Olio (8:54) and fission (he left) some minutes after that (9:07). They moved again and they were eating in the Attalea tree AB-12-263 Eva in P1 with Eli. Then they were resting for a while in P2 while Emilia was OSP around. They moved towards Chorongo 600 and they were eating in a Virola tree AB-12-015 for some time and resting there for around one hour and a half, in P1 with Eli for some time. They moved towards Pouruma PA-12-014 where they were eating and they were foraging stems and new leaves. They rest again in P1 and Emilia was on top of Eli. Then they came back to the Virola tree AB-12-015 and they were resting in the same position as before but Eli 9m away this time. They moved towards the Attalea tree again AB-08-263 and they were eating in P1 for a while. At 14:39 they fusioned with Olio who arrived and he started to eat fruits there too in P1 and P2 with Eva and Eli. At 15:08 Nenki arrived too and they left the tree and Nenki arrived and he was eating fruits for a while. A group of sakis arrived and Eli was playing with JF and AM with blue tag (Maregold and Morpho). Then the sakis left the area and at 15:22 after some VLC Sammy, Lucas and Andreo arrived. Olio approached in PC with Sammy, vocalizing for some seconds, and then Lucas and Andreo arrived to the same position where Eva was and she left. The males starting playing with Olio. At 15:56 Vita, Violeta, Vader, Evita and Elena fusioned with them. They went towards the Oenocarpus tree AB-12-339. Eva was eating in that tree in P1 with Eli and Olio, then Lucas and Sammy. Vita was in PC with Lucas he approached to her and he present his back and Vita grommed him. After some minute he did the same with Eva but she didnÕt groom him so he came back with Vita. Then Eva left proximity. In the meantime Nenki and Andreo were eating in P1 and then Vita, Violeta and Eli arrived to the tree (AB-12-339, Oenocarpus) and they were eating in P1 too. Today I went with Taylor to look for MQ-2. The weather was very rainy so it was better to try with MQ-2 because the telemetry and I showed Taylor how to use it. I explained her data collection around camp and then we went through Harpia trail and Harpia Plot line -50 and 10. We heard the signal in line 10 around 400 towards North. We went towards North and we found them around 9:23 around 500m from camp, when we could heard the signal very strong and without antenna. They were RFV and then a group of woollies arrived to the same area so I think they moved at that time and we couldnÕt heard them because the woollies movements. We followed the signal close all the time but it was raining for a while so it was difficult to see them. The first hours of the focal are not very useful because they were RFV or FV, but I left the data to know the home range too, but I am not completely sure if there were more monkeys at the beginning in the subgroup composition or only were Wentamo and Wipo, because we couldnÕt see them very good. At 11:51 they fusioned and some people arrived. They started to move and I could see Okata, Goma, Gewa and Gobi too. I started the focal in Okata to have more data on him and he was in P1 with a JM for a minute and then they continued vocalizing several times. They seemed nervous but they moved slowly. They arrived to a feeding tree AB-13-046 big green fruits which seemed cf. Sapotaceae. They were eating there and then they were resting in that tree for some time while it was raining. Okata was RFV but we could see Goma and Wentamo resting in that tree. They moved a little and they were eating in another feeding tree, orange big fruits for some minutes and then they continued moving in circles, very strangeÉ maybe because there was a new person or we were two? They moved again and Gobi was in P1 with Okata for a minute and then they rest again. Okata smelt a leave where I think Wentamo had urine. Around 15:00 Goma started to move with strange vocalizations like lost all the time and around that time I think they fissioned. So I followed Goma who move in circles again and she was eating in an Oenocarpus tree AB-13-049 and then in an emergent tree AB-13-048, tiny green fruits with red pulp with Gewa and Gobi. Then they moved again towards the Oenocarpus and they were foraging in P1 and in some point they fusioned with Wentamo, around 16:05 and they fissioned again at 16:25. I couldnÕt find Goma so I changed the focal to Wentamo again and she was resting in PC with Wipo for a while. Then they moved to eat in the Oenocarpus tree AB-13-049 in P1 Wentamo, Wipo and Gewa and they moved again towards South a little and they were eating in another tree with brown huge fruit, cf. Matisia, AB-13-050. There Wentamo nurse Wipo and they ate for some minutes and they continued South East until arrived to the sleeping tree AB-13-051, around 500 meters away line 10-850 at 17:50. We left them at 18:05 and we were very far from camp so we arrived at 19:00."OS98833		Sara Alvarez	2/24/13	1/0/00								GPS PP6	FALSE	TRUE		FALSE	"24, February, 2013 (OS98833), SA, NR

I took a fecal sample (Alvarez 13-007) from Boa underneath AB-13-039. They spent from 11:49 until 12:24 moving slowly between trees and resting. At 12:24 Mono and Buka started copulating with Boa in PC. Mono continuously grasped BukaÕs belly with his hands and at times he displayed a similar foot clasp to that of rhesus macaques when they are copulating. They also had their tails intertwined for the majority of the time. Boa was touching both of them and tried to get in the middle several times. She was very curious about the copulation. We left camp to go look for MQ-1 at 6:30. We found Andreo near G-225 and he moved towards Danta. He was eating Jacaratia in AB-13-062. There was a lot of whinnying that happened during the fusion. Soon after, there was another fusion with Olio at 7:36 and he was coming from the direction that we heard the long call earlier.
